componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Colin McGranahan with Stanford (sic) [Sanford] Bernstein.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, just on the share count. Obviously, a pretty big increase here sequentially from the fourth quarter to the first quarter, and then through the year. And it sounds like your guidance implies that you will not be buying back any stock,, whereas your
componenttext: First, just on the share count. Obviously, a pretty big increase here sequentially from the fourth quarter to the first quarter, and then through the year. And it sounds like your guidance implies that you will not be buying back any stock,, whereas your guidance just guidance absent whatever stock repurchase you do?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there are really two elements to what drives our share count. One is the shares that we issue for our employee stock plans, and then the other is shares that we buyback. I think we've said, if we were to buy back shares, it wouldn't begin until the
componenttext: Well, there are really two elements to what drives our share count. One is the shares that we issue for our employee stock plans, and then the other is shares that we buyback. I think we've said, if we were to buy back shares, it wouldn't begin until the middle of the year. And therefore, we wouldn't expect it to have a really significant impact on the total number of shares. And obviously, we don't really have a good handle on how many associates will exercise options and impact the share count in that fashion. So I would say that our guidance is pretty down the middle. It assumes that we won't see any major change from either our employee purchases or employee share plans or a share buyback, based on what we've said before about share buybacks not beginning until the middle of the year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then using your share count, it implies your EPS guidance range of operating margins for fiscal '10 in the 6.45 range to 6.9 range, about 25 to maybe 65 basis points of margin expansion. Just trying to square that again, I think Ron called it a dramat
componenttext: And then using your share count, it implies your EPS guidance range of operating margins for fiscal '10 in the 6.45 range to 6.9 range, about 25 to maybe 65 basis points of margin expansion. Just trying to square that again, I think Ron called it a dramatic improvement in international. Mike said it's significant step in profitability and international. If you have that, that would suggest that either Retail, with positive comps, leveraging rent and labor, or Delivery, with positive top-line growth, is really going to see any margin improvement at all or there's any incremental synergies to the business at all. So I'm just really trying to square that. And I guess I'm having trouble understanding why there isn't leverage in the model, given the top line growth in the international improvement.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think as we say, all of the opportunities and the challenges we have in 2010, we have really the two sides of it. We don't really know what the economy's good to do. As I mentioned, we aren't planning for a dramatic improvement in the economy. And at th
componenttext: I think as we say, all of the opportunities and the challenges we have in 2010, we have really the two sides of it. We don't really know what the economy's good to do. As I mentioned, we aren't planning for a dramatic improvement in the economy. And at the same time, we'd have pretty good success with some of the growth initiatives that we think are going to position us well for the longer term. So I think that the investments that we make against a relatively low single-digit sales gain will result in what we think are -- in the base business, you will see dramatic improvement. You will see the base improve, but you'll see investment in the growth areas offsetting a substantial portion of that. And the aggregate effect of that is we'll have what we think is decent operating margin expansion. And we'll manage that throughout the year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just finally, so, Ron, you said the incentive comp in the fourth quarter was 70 basis point impact?
componenttext: And then just finally, so, Ron, you said the incentive comp in the fourth quarter was 70 basis point impact?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it was.
componenttext: Yes, it was.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Baker from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Baker from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you characterize the promotional environments, both in Retail as well as in the Delivery business? Are you seeing people aggressively go after new contracts?
componenttext: Can you characterize the promotional environments, both in Retail as well as in the Delivery business? Are you seeing people aggressively go after new contracts?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say that the environment is essentially the same as it's been. Obviously, everybody was working through the worst previous quarters. So in Q4, we really didn't see anything particularly aggressive come through. I think towards the end of the quarter,
componenttext: I'd say that the environment is essentially the same as it's been. Obviously, everybody was working through the worst previous quarters. So in Q4, we really didn't see anything particularly aggressive come through. I think towards the end of the quarter, there was a little bit more activity as we headed into January, but nothing too noteworthy.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the Delivery side, Michael, I think you can say it continues to be competitive, but rational. So we don't see anything out of the ordinary out there.
componenttext: On the Delivery side, Michael, I think you can say it continues to be competitive, but rational. So we don't see anything out of the ordinary out there.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: So based on those comments and what I think you can infer from your guidance, it sounds like you expect that to continue, and then gross profit margins to be favorable in 2010?
componenttext: So based on those comments and what I think you can infer from your guidance, it sounds like you expect that to continue, and then gross profit margins to be favorable in 2010?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you could shed, just a little like strategically on the technology effort that you talked about in North American Delivery. I know you had a press release a week or so ago, discussing the [indiscernible]effort, what kind of size you'd anticipate for th
componenttext: If you could shed, just a little like strategically on the technology effort that you talked about in North American Delivery. I know you had a press release a week or so ago, discussing the [indiscernible]effort, what kind of size you'd anticipate for that business over the next year or two? Because I know you had your clear [ph] of technology or just two different [ph] technologies and delivery purpose [ph]?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start it all, I'll turn it over to Joe Doody. I think we're really talking about two initiatives, but really one initiative, both related to technology. I think on the Retail side, we think there's an opportunity to sell a lot more technology to ou
componenttext: Let me start it all, I'll turn it over to Joe Doody. I think we're really talking about two initiatives, but really one initiative, both related to technology. I think on the Retail side, we think there's an opportunity to sell a lot more technology to our retail customers and our catalog customers, which I think is about assortment, it's about the service, it's about building relationship, it's EasyTech. And then the announcement that we made a few weeks ago was Staples Technology Solutions, which is a combination of a business that we purchased a few years ago, plus one of the lines of business that we acquired with Corporate Express. And we put those two together and call them Staples Technology Solutions. And Joe, you might want to give some color commentary on that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think just to go back to your first point, Ron, I think we feel that there's certainly is opportunity throughout all of North American Delivery for technology sales and getting a fair share of technology business out there among our existing custom
componenttext: Yes, I think just to go back to your first point, Ron, I think we feel that there's certainly is opportunity throughout all of North American Delivery for technology sales and getting a fair share of technology business out there among our existing customers. So it's clearly an area that we can leverage our customer relationships with, leverage our vendor relationships with, leverage our supply chain to bring more technology solutions to our customer base. And as Ron said, with the acquisition of Corporate Express, we've certainly picked up some additional capabilities. We really want to rebrand those under the Staples name. And that's the announcement that you saw recently, bundling some capabilities together. And it's not a significant business today, but certainly has significant growth opportunities for it.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Accounting clean-up items, for John, related to your currency assumptions, your tax rate assumptions. And then also just clarifying on amortization, perhaps this is common knowledge but it looks like your guiding amortization down year-on-year from 2009?
componenttext: Accounting clean-up items, for John, related to your currency assumptions, your tax rate assumptions. And then also just clarifying on amortization, perhaps this is common knowledge but it looks like your guiding amortization down year-on-year from 2009? I just want to make sure we got some [indiscernible]on that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Amortization is the easy one, to starting off. There were a number of items that related to the brands that we had in Europe that we've accelerated the amortization on, as we plan to face into the Staples brand. And that's the reason that amortizati
componenttext: Sure. Amortization is the easy one, to starting off. There were a number of items that related to the brands that we had in Europe that we've accelerated the amortization on, as we plan to face into the Staples brand. And that's the reason that amortization for those goes down. We have higher rates over the shorter life that we use, based on the transition plan. From a currency perspective, obviously, currencies have been pretty volatile. We've assumed essentially with consensus four or great would indicate for currencies for 2010. So it'll be a little bit volatile but generally speaking, it will hurt us during the year we expect. And the tax rate, we expect the tax rate will be similar to this year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brad Thomas with Keybanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brad Thomas with Keybanc Capital Markets.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on the increased investments for this year, specifically CapEx. Could you just talk a little bit more about the areas of investment and the time frame that you might hope to get a return?
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on the increased investments for this year, specifically CapEx. Could you just talk a little bit more about the areas of investment and the time frame that you might hope to get a return?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think we've made it clear that integration continues to require some CapEx. Some of that in the systems area, some of that will be in facilities. We also have made planned investments to support the tech initiatives and the Copy & Print ini
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think we've made it clear that integration continues to require some CapEx. Some of that in the systems area, some of that will be in facilities. We also have made planned investments to support the tech initiatives and the Copy & Print initiatives in our Retail business. All of those, we would expect to get returns on our normal time frames. In stores, we see return generally within the first couple of years. And with the expenses for integration or the CapEx for integration, that will be part of what enables us to drive our operating margin rate up in NAB. And then finally, in Europe, we've seen some investments both in distribution and delivery as well as some systems as we implement SAP throughout Europe. All of those would show a return on the very near term.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on the Retail comp performance. When you look at it on a two-year rate, it looks like perhaps a little bit of a slow down. It sounds also like the technology category, a big driver, often perhaps a little bit of a consumer-related
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on the Retail comp performance. When you look at it on a two-year rate, it looks like perhaps a little bit of a slow down. It sounds also like the technology category, a big driver, often perhaps a little bit of a consumer-related category rather than a business category. Can you just talk a little bit more about what you're seeing in terms of the small business spending trends?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just overall, the thing that I am excited about is the customer count showing the best improvement that we've seen in quite some time. I don't know about strict breakout of business-to-consumer traffic counts at the moment, but the trends are encouraging.
componenttext: Just overall, the thing that I am excited about is the customer count showing the best improvement that we've seen in quite some time. I don't know about strict breakout of business-to-consumer traffic counts at the moment, but the trends are encouraging. Also, the tech focus for us is really on business tech. And as business, hopefully, gets back to work, this is an opportunity for us to really go after that, which honestly is I know [indiscernible] we feel it's not fully served right now. So it's an exciting opportunity. Obviously, it's a low-margin business. We'll have to do a much better job at filling out the sale and really getting customers what they need, selling a complete solution. And it's going to take a stronger focus on how we actually staff our store, pay our associates and really fulfill every customers' needs.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Binder with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Dan Binder with Jefferies.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, on the $20 million hit you're taking between the Print Systems business, China. I'm just curious what you would anticipate the direction of that to look like over the coming quarters? Is this just sort of a trough on that, and it's going to get bet
componenttext: First, on the $20 million hit you're taking between the Print Systems business, China. I'm just curious what you would anticipate the direction of that to look like over the coming quarters? Is this just sort of a trough on that, and it's going to get better from here? Or do you expect that to run at that level for a couple of quarters before new management can impact China, in particular? And then second question was on the impact that technology had on gross margin. If you have the breakdown in terms of was it 10 basis points, 20 basis points [indiscernible].

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dan, it's Mike Miles. On the print systems in China, the vast majority of that was on China, as opposed to last quarter when we had about the same sort of issues but the majority was print systems. I expect print systems will look a lot better in 2010, th
componenttext: Dan, it's Mike Miles. On the print systems in China, the vast majority of that was on China, as opposed to last quarter when we had about the same sort of issues but the majority was print systems. I expect print systems will look a lot better in 2010, than it did for us in 2009, largely as a result of the steps that we took in 2009. I don't think the business is going to improve a whole lot, but we've right sized the cost structure there. China is a little bit more of a longer-term project for us. As I mentioned, we've had some management changes there. And although I think the long-term prospects for us there are very bright, I think we may have a little more pain to go through there before things really look a lot better.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, Dan, your second question was on the impact of technology on our total gross margin? I'm not sure I have that.
componenttext: And then, Dan, your second question was on the impact of technology on our total gross margin? I'm not sure I have that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, overall, I don't have the exact number either. I think we saw overall that we saw 50 basis points of improvement in our gross margin rate. And that was driven by integration synergies, but offset slightly by the impact of the changed mix in t
componenttext: Yes, I mean, overall, I don't have the exact number either. I think we saw overall that we saw 50 basis points of improvement in our gross margin rate. And that was driven by integration synergies, but offset slightly by the impact of the changed mix in technology in the retail stores. That's not a really huge impact on the whole, but it did moderate the improvement that we saw.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Kate McShane with Citi Investment Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Kate McShane with Citi Investment Research.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, now that you have a few months in Europe under your belt, can you talk a little bit about what you've learned that maybe you didn't know before, both on the positive side and the negative side? And can you go into a little bit more detail on your ne
componenttext: Mike, now that you have a few months in Europe under your belt, can you talk a little bit about what you've learned that maybe you didn't know before, both on the positive side and the negative side? And can you go into a little bit more detail on your new mid-market contract strategy in Europe?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, in general, the European business is one that has a number of very strong operations in it. You look around, some of the -- it's both up in the Nordics, in Southern Europe, in our Catalog business, we've got some strong operations. We've also rea
componenttext: I think, in general, the European business is one that has a number of very strong operations in it. You look around, some of the -- it's both up in the Nordics, in Southern Europe, in our Catalog business, we've got some strong operations. We've also really improved our Retail business there over the years. I think three or four years ago, we were struggling to break even in Germany at Retail. That business is now approaching U.S. levels of profitability and on a nice trend. So I think there are some places in Europe where I think we're ready to invest today even though the overall operating profit level there is still below where we want it to be. With respect to mid-market, I think there's, particularly in Germany and the U.K., a nice opportunity for us to leverage the contract infrastructure that we've got in place there, and add the mid-market sales force model that has worked so well for Joe and the NAD team here in North America. You won't be surprised to learn that we're exporting people from Joe's team, who are experts on that model, to Europe to help lead that effort. And we've already got the first people on the ground, and are beginning to add sales people in that space as we speak. Obviously, it's something that needs to build over time, because you need to ramp the sales force to really drive the business. But we're optimistic that we can do the same thing over there that we have with SBA here in the U.S.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: One technical question. Of the 40 stores you're opening in North America in 2010, did you say how many were Copy & Print standalone stores?
componenttext: One technical question. Of the 40 stores you're opening in North America in 2010, did you say how many were Copy & Print standalone stores?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: We didn't, but it's a handful.
componenttext: We didn't, but it's a handful.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, four to five.
componenttext: Yes, four to five.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Oliver Wintermantel with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Oliver Wintermantel with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Regarding the back-to-business season, if you compare January 2010 to a more normalized January, instead of January 2009, how is January 2010 in terms of sales volume and sales mix, compare consumables and more durables?
componenttext: Regarding the back-to-business season, if you compare January 2010 to a more normalized January, instead of January 2009, how is January 2010 in terms of sales volume and sales mix, compare consumables and more durables?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know that I've looked at it that way, but off the top of my head, I would say that probably 2010 look a lot more like 2007, 2008 kind of month in terms of mix of products, maybe it's slightly more skewed toward technology, as our business has evol
componenttext: I don't know that I've looked at it that way, but off the top of my head, I would say that probably 2010 look a lot more like 2007, 2008 kind of month in terms of mix of products, maybe it's slightly more skewed toward technology, as our business has evolve more toward technology. But certainly, 2010 much better than '09, and kind of your typical January. There has been some product mix shifts, but nothing dramatic.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Balter with Crdit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Gary Balter with Crdit Suisse.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: First one is there's been discussions about possibly you giving up market share and contract, as you bring Corporate Express in, just customers that you felt didn't fit in with your longer-term goals. Yet your results where still stronger than the other t
componenttext: First one is there's been discussions about possibly you giving up market share and contract, as you bring Corporate Express in, just customers that you felt didn't fit in with your longer-term goals. Yet your results where still stronger than the other two. Could you discuss what your plans are? I know you're kind of done with reviewing all the contracts?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'll make a summary comment. Then, I'll turn it over to Joe. I mean, I'm a kind of a analytical guy. And the numbers are the numbers. So you can just kind of look to see that we're obviously not losing share. But, Joe?
componenttext: Yes, I'll make a summary comment. Then, I'll turn it over to Joe. I mean, I'm a kind of a analytical guy. And the numbers are the numbers. So you can just kind of look to see that we're obviously not losing share. But, Joe?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. You're  right, Ron, the numbers are the numbers. So sequentially, as I said, we had about 1,000-point improvement, Q3 to Q4. And our major two competitors, at least, had dramatically less sequential improvement than that or at least one of them isn't
componenttext: Yes. You're  right, Ron, the numbers are the numbers. So sequentially, as I said, we had about 1,000-point improvement, Q3 to Q4. And our major two competitors, at least, had dramatically less sequential improvement than that or at least one of them isn't[ph] sure. But we're continually, Gary, looking at contracts, whether they be CE contracts or Staples contracts, to ensure that we're driving the level of account profitability. And we do that, obviously, through our lowest cost-to-deliver model that we worked with the customers, to really drive savings for them, drive savings for us and drive some of the key metrics that you know helps that profitability, like average order size, number of small orders, electronic penetration, et cetera. So it's ever [ph] ending, whether it be the CE-based or not. But I think we've done most of what we need to do there, and it's really fully integrated into the business. And we're treating those customers the same as we treat our Staples customers.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the follow up is longer term, you gave us guidance in 9%. I believe it's pretax, but maybe operating margin. We're projecting you'll be at 6 2 now for 2010 which is up nicely from this past year. Do you think you'll be at that 9% before Canada defends
componenttext: And the follow up is longer term, you gave us guidance in 9%. I believe it's pretax, but maybe operating margin. We're projecting you'll be at 6 2 now for 2010 which is up nicely from this past year. Do you think you'll be at that 9% before Canada defends their gold medal in Sochi?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Canadians certainly did on the podium this time. That's all I can say.
componenttext: The Canadians certainly did on the podium this time. That's all I can say.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Gary, it all depends on the economy. I mean, I think we're starting to see some nice recovery. I think that bodes well for 2010. I think it bodes even better for 2011. So given that they won't have a chance to defend their gold medal until the '1
componenttext: I think, Gary, it all depends on the economy. I mean, I think we're starting to see some nice recovery. I think that bodes well for 2010. I think it bodes even better for 2011. So given that they won't have a chance to defend their gold medal until the '14, yes.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Alan Rifkin with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alan Rifkin with Bank of America.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ron, on the North American Delivery side, I believe you said contracts was down low singles and Quill, down mid-singles. How much of a function of the lower marketing expenses do you believe that those two businesses exhibited? And going forward in 2010,
componenttext: Ron, on the North American Delivery side, I believe you said contracts was down low singles and Quill, down mid-singles. How much of a function of the lower marketing expenses do you believe that those two businesses exhibited? And going forward in 2010, will we see an increase on the marketing side, to hopefully boost those two sides of the business?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I would argue, I think we're spending marketing wisely and adequately. I think the big benefit from marketing is moving it from catalog and many of the things we've done historically to more of a online and kind of direct sales force-type marketin
componenttext: I guess I would argue, I think we're spending marketing wisely and adequately. I think the big benefit from marketing is moving it from catalog and many of the things we've done historically to more of a online and kind of direct sales force-type marketing. I don't think our lack of marketing expense impacted our sales. I think it was really just a function of the economy. And in our Contract business, if you don't have people working, you don't have people consuming office supplies. And I think the early indications are that maybe the job situation has stabilized, and we're hoping to see some improvement from here. Joe, again, anything to add?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, Ron. I think we agree with what you said. Nothing further to add.
componenttext: No, Ron. I think we agree with what you said. Nothing further to add.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, with respect to the international profitability significantly improving in 2010 after being down in Q4, can you just shed a little bit more color on that? Is that more function of a significant increase in productivity? And where is the break-even p
componenttext: Mike, with respect to the international profitability significantly improving in 2010 after being down in Q4, can you just shed a little bit more color on that? Is that more function of a significant increase in productivity? And where is the break-even point with respect to expense leverage on the international side from a comp standpoint?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Alan, it's really more driven by the expense reductions, many of which we've implemented already in 2009. And the expenses that, frankly, we incurred associated with some of that, not being around in 2010. It's not driven so much by sales leverage, althou
componenttext: Alan, it's really more driven by the expense reductions, many of which we've implemented already in 2009. And the expenses that, frankly, we incurred associated with some of that, not being around in 2010. It's not driven so much by sales leverage, although, obviously, that helps. And if we were to have a significant leg down, that would obviously hurt. I think given a reasonable economic prospect and picture in 2010, we expect to get significant leverage from the better buying that we're doing. And as I said, those negotiations have all been completed. And so we really know what that's going to be. From the headcount reduction that we achieved through the works council negotiations in 2009 and again, although not all of that has been implemented, it's all been negotiated. And so we know what that's going to be. And through the supply chain consolidations that we are and still in the midst of, we're going from roughly 37 warehouses in Europe down to something like half that, but we're already halfway there. And so those savings are kicking in as well. So I think we're not done, there's other stuff that we want to get done. But a lot of the reason that you hear some confidence in my voice when I talk about improved profitability, it's because we've implemented a lot of the measures that will deliver that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: At this time, there are no further questions. I would now like to turn the call back over to Ron Sargent for closing remarks.
componenttext: At this time, there are no further questions. I would now like to turn the call back over to Ron Sargent for closing remarks.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks everybody for joining us this morning. We look forward to speaking to all of you again very soon. Thanks, everybody.
componenttext: Thanks everybody for joining us this morning. We look forward to speaking to all of you again very soon. Thanks, everybody.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes the presentation and you may now disconnect. Thank you, and have a good day.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes the presentation and you may now disconnect. Thank you, and have a good day.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Staples Earning Conference Call. My name is Oniga, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would now like to turn the call over to M
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2009 Staples Earning Conference Call. My name is Oniga, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] At this time, I would now like to turn the call over to Ms. Laurel Lefebvre, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone and thanks for joining us for our Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2009 Earnings Announcement. During today's call, we'll discuss some non-GAAP metrics to provide investors with useful information about our financial performance. Please se
componenttext: Good morning, everyone and thanks for joining us for our Fourth Quarter and Fiscal 2009 Earnings Announcement. During today's call, we'll discuss some non-GAAP metrics to provide investors with useful information about our financial performance. Please see the financial measures and other data section of the Investor Information portion of staples.com for an explanation and reconciliation of such measures and other calculations of financial measures that we use to analyze our business.I'd also like to remind you that certain information discussed on this call constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the Safe Harbor Provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by such forward-looking statements as a result of various important factors, including those discussed or referenced under the heading Risk Factors and elsewhere in Staples' latest 10-Q filed this morning.Here to discuss Staples' Q4 and fiscal '09 performance and business outlook are Ron Sargent, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Miles, President and Chief Operating Officer; and John Mahoney, Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer. Also joining us are Demos Parneros, President of U.S. Stores; and Joe Doody, President of North American Delivery. Ron?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, Laurel and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. I'm pleased to report strong fourth quarter results this morning and I'm very happy that we're getting back to growing the business again.During Q4, sales trends were encouragi
componenttext: Well, thanks, Laurel and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. I'm pleased to report strong fourth quarter results this morning and I'm very happy that we're getting back to growing the business again.During Q4, sales trends were encouraging, particularly in North America, where our Retail business got back to positive comps. Staples Business Delivery grew sales for the first time in six quarters, and our Contract business showed nice signs of recovery.Both SBD and Contract improved their toplines by more than 10 percentage points compared to last quarter. We're gaining traction in our International business and saw strength in European Catalog and Contract as well as in South America.In terms of the Q4 headlines, total sales were up 4% versus last year to $6.4 billion. North American Retail comps were positive for the first time in 10 quarters. Adjusted earnings per share increased 6% to $0.38. And we ended the year with record free cash flow of $1.8 billion.By sticking to our recession plan of providing great service, managing expenses and investing in growth ideas, we had a lot done in 2009. Our team made great progress on the integration of Corporate Express in North America and Europe. We took big steps toward building one global Staples brand. We laid a solid foundation for growth in Tech Services and Copy & Print businesses, and we strengthened the leadership of our International business.As we look to the year ahead, we're pretty excited about our opportunities in 2010. While we're not planning for a big economic recovery this year, we do plan on getting back to growing both the top and bottom lines.One of the big biggest drivers of this growth where we'll be investing in growing adjacent categories like facilities and breakroom supplies, business technology and Copy & Print, all while continuing to grow sales in core office supplies.  We'll accomplish major milestones on the CE integration. We'll continue to open a new store every week, and we'll dramatically improve the profitability of our International business.All the work we've done to respond to our customers' needs positions us well to drive growth in our core offering while taking the business in new directions. I've never been more confident that we've got the right people and the right plan to take full advantage of the opportunities we have in front of us.Now turning to our business units, starting with North American Delivery. Sales for the fourth quarter were $2.4 billion, down about 1%. And while we're not quite back to growth in delivery, we were encouraged by the improving trends we saw throughout the quarter as the top line in each of our Delivery businesses improved sequentially.In Staples Business Delivery, we grew the top line in the mid-single digits. In Contract, sales declined in the low-single digits. And in Quill, the top line declined in the mid-single digits. NAD operating margin improved 24 basis points to 9.2% compared to the same period last year. Synergies from better buying, combining two sales forces, closing warehouses, and reducing marketing expense all helped operating margin. On the other hand, higher incentive compensation weighed on profitability. Contract customers also remained cautious with discretionary purchases, the mixed shift to On-Contract, lower margin products continued to moderate during the fourth quarter, and was only a modest drag of about 10 basis points on NAD product margin.During the fourth quarter, we signed several new government accounts, continuing the trend that we've seen throughout 2009. Our Government business grew by about 11% in Q4. We're right on track with the integration of Corporate Express in North America. During the fourth quarter, we integrated key finance systems and consolidated accounts payable activities to our shared services center in South Carolina. We completed the consolidation of our office products assortment, and we're currently rationalizing assortment in facility supplies, furniture and our other lines of business.We've wrapped up our brand transition in North America and we also made great progress with the integration of our distribution network. A few weeks ago, we went live with our first distribution center that will serve both Staples and legacy Corporate Express customers.Looking back at the past year, I'm extremely proud of how hard our team has worked and the progress we've made with the integration. During 2009, we hit our targets for direct and indirect buying synergies. We reduced small orders, increased average order size and the improved account profitability. We finalized our assortment and combined the Corporate Express and Staples brands, paving the way for our 2010 full-line catalog which featured one common product assortment. We combined our sales force and got all of our sales associates on the same compensation and benefits plans. We consolidated human resource and finance systems. We rationalized our transportation network and began using the rebranded Corporate Express fleet to deliver Staples products. And we leveraged our new lines of business to win more than $200 million of new business in adjacent categories like furniture, printing and technology solutions. At the same time, we managed working capital extremely well. Our shared services team dramatically improved DSO, and our supply chain team increased inventory turns resulting in strong free cash flow for NAD.Despite how far we've come in the 21 months since we acquired Corporate Express, we still have a lot of work to do. During 2010, we'll complete the majority of our supply chain network integration and consolidate a handful of fulfillment centers. We'll also be heavily focused on the design and testing of our single common e-commerce ordering platform, which will be a big improvement over our legacy ordering systems.During 2009, we made great progress developing our lines of business and in 2010, we're going to make an even bigger push into these adjacent categories, where our existing customers want us to provide them with solutions. We recently launched Staples Technology Solutions to provide business customers with a one-stop shop for data center and desktop technology products as well as network services. We'll also invest in growing facilities and breakroom supplies, where our capabilities have improved with the acquisition of Corporate Express. We're confident that we can grow this category to become a much more meaningful piece of our business over the next coming years.Moving on to North American Retail. Sales for the fourth quarter were $2.6 billion. That was an increase of 8% or 4% in local currency versus Q4 of 2008. Fourth quarter same-store sales rose 3%. Customer count comps increased 4% compared to Q4 2008, and that's the strongest increase in traffic we've seen in more than three years.Average order size continues to improve sequentially, but remain negative compared to last year. Average order size was down about 1%. We saw double-digit top line growth in categories where we've made big investments like computers and ink. And we also relative strength in multifunction devices, tech peripherals and core office supplies. Our Services business also performed well during the fourth quarter. The Copy & Print Center achieved high-single digit top line growth while improving the bottom line. And our EasyTech business doubled versus the fourth quarter of 2008.We continue to improve our price impression with customers in the fourth quarter with strong performance during both the holiday and back-to-business seasons. Price and value remain top of mind and many of our traffic driving initiatives like great deals on laptops and other tech products, 50% back in Rewards, double rewards on ink and strong paper offers really struck a chord with our customers. And while we're seeing increased traffic in our stores, we haven't taken our eye off the ball with customer service. And I'm happy to report that our customer satisfaction scores hit all-time highs during the fourth quarter.North American retail operating margin increased 21 basis points to 9.5% for the quarter. Gross profit continues to benefit from purchasing synergies, and we leveraged rent and distribution expenses during the quarter. These improvements were somewhat offset by an increased mix of lower margin technology products. We did a good job with the operating and selling expenses, particularly in marketing where we continue to reduce costs by moving more of our marketing online. These improvements were somewhat offset by increased incentive compensation, as the team drove better results in North American Retail.  We also worked hard managing working capital in North American Retail, reducing inventory per store by 5% and driving a 34 basis point improvement in inventory turns compared to last year's levels, all while improving customer service and in stock levels and driving the top line.During the fourth quarter, we opened four stores and we closed five. And for the full year, we opened 48 stores and closed 12 stores in North America. We ended the year with a total of 1,871 stores in North America, 1,555 in the United States and 316 in Canada. The commercial real estate market remains very attractive and in 2010, we'll continue to be very selective with the locations of our new store openings. We expect to open about 40 new stores in North America for the full year, around 35 in the United States and five in Canada.In addition to investing in new stores, we're also going to drive growth by making investments in attractive categories where we have very low market share like Business Technology and Copy & Print. We've made great strides in improving the quality of our offering and broadening our assortment. But to succeed in these categories, we're going to need to think differently about how we serve our customers. This year, we'll invest in people, training and store remodels to become a much more credible player here.And with that, I'll turn it over to Mike to talk about International.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ron. Good morning, everybody. Sales for the fourth quarter in International were $1.4 billion, an increase of about 7% in U.S. dollars and a decrease of about 6% local currency compared to the same period last year. Operating margin was 4.1% of sa
componenttext: Thanks, Ron. Good morning, everybody. Sales for the fourth quarter in International were $1.4 billion, an increase of about 7% in U.S. dollars and a decrease of about 6% local currency compared to the same period last year. Operating margin was 4.1% of sales, a decrease of 38 basis points from Q4 2008. Our Office Products business in Europe, which makes up a little more than 70% of our total International sales showed relative strength. Profit improvement initiatives we've put in place are gaining traction, and the operating margin of that business improved by almost 100 basis points during the fourth quarter, with operating margin expansion across all channels: Retail, Catalog and Contract.However, the progress that we're making there was offset by losses in the Print Systems division in Europe and our business in China. Together, these two units lost $20 million in the fourth quarter compared to a small profit a year ago.The Print Systems division has done a good job, rightsizing for continued soft sales in 2010, reducing headcount by 11%. We expect PSD to post better results in the coming year.In China, although the top line trend showed some moderation during the fourth quarter, we continue to face double digit sales declines and steep losses. Jeff Jin, the former Chairman of Staples China has left the business, and we have a strong team on the ground including a new CFO and Head of Human Resources working with our COO to get that business back on track.In Europe, Catalog sales grew in the low single digits in local currency versus Q4 of last year, with particular strength in our French businesses. Catalog operating margin improved as a result of better product mix and purchasing synergy. Contract sales were flat in local currency versus last year, although the Nordics region had a very strong performance. Contract margins improved nicely due to the strength in our office supplies and cost saving measures. In-store sales in the European Retail declined 8% during the fourth quarter. The decline was driven entirely by durable, especially technology with positive comps for consumables based by double-digit growth for ink. As a result, our gross margin comp was flat despite of the soft sales. Overall profitability for the Retail segment remains strong with operating margins increasing.Turning to the Corporate Express integration in Europe, we completed the majority of our direct and indirect vendor negotiations during the fourth quarter. We made progress with the rationalization of our warehouse network across Europe, completing the consolidation of Contract and Catalog warehouses in Spain, and transitioning our German Catalog operations from Brussels to Stuttgart.We're in the midst of the rebranding of all Contract facilities in Europe. And over the last month have re-signed our retail stores in Scandinavia from Corporate Express brands to Staples.Outside of Europe, Corporate Express Australia did a good job driving profit improvement despite soft sales during the fourth quarter. Our business in South America drove top line growth and significantly improved its profitability year-over-year. And our joint venture in India continues to grow quickly on pace with our expectations.Last quarter, I outlined three priorities for International: People, profitability and portfolio. On the people front, we recently named John Barton, Executive Vice President, International Development, with direct responsibility for our high-growth markets and an overall charter for implementing Staples' best practices around the world.John just celebrated his 20th anniversary at Staples, and has led our real estate function for the last six. That experience will be invaluable as we ramp up new store growth in Europe with 10 new stores in our 2010 plan. On profitability, the progress we're making with the integration of Corporate Express will be a key contributor to improving profitability. The integration in Europe got started about a year after North America, and a large portion of the buying, G&A and supply chain efficiencies that we focused on throughout 2009 will start to show up in our 2010 results.I mentioned the improved profitability of the Print Systems division, and we expect continued progress toward better profitability in our high-growth markets. I remain confident that we will take the significant step forward on International profitability in 2010.Our International portfolio strategy is all about focusing on a relatively small number of markets where we can build a strong profitable multichannel business, maximizing scale and minimizing G&A. We won't hesitate to pull back from unprofitable markets. During the fourth quarter, we closed our two Office Centre stores in Germany and exited our Catalog businesses in Hungary and the Czech Republic, bringing our total countries with operations outside of North America down to 23 from 25.At the same time, we're moving forward with investments in some of our priority markets. New store growth and investment in building a mid-market contract sales force. The more I learn about our International business, the more bullish I am about our opportunities.Now I'd like to turn it over to John to review our financials.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. In the fourth quarter, total company sales were up 4% versus last year to $6.4 billion. The foreign exchange impact from the weaker U.S. dollar helped the top line by about 450 basis points during Q4, with about 40% of this benefit coming fr
componenttext: Thanks, Mike. In the fourth quarter, total company sales were up 4% versus last year to $6.4 billion. The foreign exchange impact from the weaker U.S. dollar helped the top line by about 450 basis points during Q4, with about 40% of this benefit coming from Canada.For the full year, total company sales were up 5% to $24.3 billion. If you adjust our 2008 sales to include $3.4 billion of Corporate Express sales prior to the acquisition, our top line declined about 8% versus last year. Our fourth GAAP earnings per share on a fully diluted basis decreased 20% to $0.32 a share versus the fourth quarter of 2008.A few weeks ago, we announced the settlement of several retail wage in hour class action lawsuits, for which we recorded a $42 million pretax expense. We also incurred $20 million of pretax integration and restructuring expenses in Q4. Excluding those two items, adjusted earnings per share increased to 6% to $0.38 per share versus the fourth quarter of 2008. Q4 2008 adjusted earnings per share excluded pretax integration and restructuring expense of $41 million and a $57 million tax gain.Favorable foreign currency exchange rates benefited EPS this quarter by about $0.02. For the full year, adjusted earnings per share declined 12% to $1.14 compared to last year's $1.29.Gross profit margin improved by 55 basis points to 27.4% during the fourth quarter. This reflects stronger product margins driven by purchasing synergies, efficiencies in delivery and distribution expense and leveraged rent expense, partially offset by a higher mix of lower margins in technology sales particularly in North American Retail.On an adjusted basis, SG&A delevered 38 basis points versus last year's fourth quarter to 19.5% of sales. This was driven by increased incentive compensation offset by leverage on the labor line, integration synergies and marketing efficiencies. And adjusted operating margin increased 70 basis points during the fourth quarter to 7.6%. 2009 capital expenditures came in at $313 million, down from the $378 million we spent during 2008. With operating cash flow of about $2.1 billion, we generated a record $1.8 billion free cash flow for the year, versus $1.3 billion in 2008.In 2010, we're planning to increase our capital expenditures to $450 million as we invest in growth initiatives, new stores, remodels, systems and the integration of our distribution networks in North America and Europe. We expect that cash flow will remain strong during 2010. However, we don't have the same degree of integration-related working capital or tax opportunities that we had in 2009. We also may invest in inventory to support improving sales trends throughout the year. We plan to spend about $140 million more in capital this year, and are expecting to generate more than $1 billion of free cash flow in 2010.Looking ahead to the first quarter, we expect total company sales to increase in the mid-single digits versus Q1 of 2009. We expect adjusted earnings per share, excluding integration and restructuring expense, in the range of $0.25 to $0.27 for the first quarter of 2010.We expect total company sales for the full year to increase in the low-single digits versus 2009. We expect to achieve adjusted earnings per share, excluding integration and restructuring expense, in the range of $1.23 to $1.33. This EPS guidance assumes a modest economic recovery throughout 2010 and increased investment in our growth ideas like Business Technology, Copy & Print, new stores, launching of mid-market Contract offering in Europe and adjacent categories such as facilities and breakroom supplies.Let me give you some more detail on our expectations for the P&L. We expect depreciation expense to be $115 million to $125 million in the first quarter, and $470 million to $490 million for the full year. We anticipate amortization expense to be $15 million to $20 million for the first quarter, and $65 million to $75 million for the full year. Integration and restructuring expense is expected to be front-end loaded during 2010, with $25 million to $30 million in the first quarter and $50 million to $60 million for the full year. And net interest expense is expected to be $55 million to $60 million in the first quarter, and $225 million to $235 million for the full year. In terms of share count, you should expect about 735 million to 740 million shares for the first quarter, and 740 million to 745 million for the full year.Thanks for your time this morning, and I will now turn the call back over to our conference moderator for Q&A.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Chris Horvers with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Chris Horvers with JPMorgan.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, a detailed question. Could you, John, quantify how much incentive comp impacted earnings in the fourth quarter? And perhaps, was that a reversal that you were going against in the prior year and how we should think about that cascading into next ye
componenttext: First, a detailed question. Could you, John, quantify how much incentive comp impacted earnings in the fourth quarter? And perhaps, was that a reversal that you were going against in the prior year and how we should think about that cascading into next year, particularly the fourth quarter?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, obviously, we paid no bonus at all in 2009 and therefore there would've been an immaterial reversal in the fourth quarter. But in total, the impact would have resulted in SG&A leveraging this year, had it not been for the incentive compensation.
componenttext: Well, obviously, we paid no bonus at all in 2009 and therefore there would've been an immaterial reversal in the fourth quarter. But in total, the impact would have resulted in SG&A leveraging this year, had it not been for the incentive compensation.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: 2008, we paid no bonus. In 2009, we did pay bonus and it was like in the fourth quarter, basis points in the 70 range?
componenttext: 2008, we paid no bonus. In 2009, we did pay bonus and it was like in the fourth quarter, basis points in the 70 range?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. Yes, I meant to say we did not pay a bonus for last year. This year, we expect to pay a bonus. And the impact of that would have resulted in leveraging SG&A.
componenttext: Right. Yes, I meant to say we did not pay a bonus for last year. This year, we expect to pay a bonus. And the impact of that would have resulted in leveraging SG&A.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. Because you deleveraged 70 basis points and you would've leveraged slightly x that?
componenttext: Right. Because you deleveraged 70 basis points and you would've leveraged slightly x that?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. SG&A deleveraged by 38 basis points. And if it hadn't been for the incentive comp, we would've leveraged.
componenttext: No. SG&A deleveraged by 38 basis points. And if it hadn't been for the incentive comp, we would've leveraged.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And so as we think about next year, you'll have more of a kind of regular accrual rate. So there should be some pressure in the early part of the year and then a benefit in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: And so as we think about next year, you'll have more of a kind of regular accrual rate. So there should be some pressure in the early part of the year and then a benefit in the fourth quarter?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'd expect that to be true. Our bonus levels would be expected to be about the same as they are this year, next year.
componenttext: Yes, I'd expect that to be true. Our bonus levels would be expected to be about the same as they are this year, next year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I think that the big surprise for us, as we think about your 2010 guidance isn't the sales, because the sales are basically in line, it's the amount of leverage in the model. Clearly, a lot of investment going on with stores and technology and distrib
componenttext: And I think that the big surprise for us, as we think about your 2010 guidance isn't the sales, because the sales are basically in line, it's the amount of leverage in the model. Clearly, a lot of investment going on with stores and technology and distribution domestically, internationally. Could you talk about, maybe put some numbers around how much that is in terms of dollars? How that cascades through the year, and how we should think about just your leverage point as the year progresses?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think there's really two factors there. One is we expect that as the year goes on, unless we see a pick up in the economy, that the comparison are going to be more difficult. Therefore, we're expecting to see higher growth rate in sales at the beginning
componenttext: I think there's really two factors there. One is we expect that as the year goes on, unless we see a pick up in the economy, that the comparison are going to be more difficult. Therefore, we're expecting to see higher growth rate in sales at the beginning of the year than in the back half of the year. So that's one element of what you can expect to see on leverage. The other is, obviously, as we think about investments in some of our growth categories, some of those are capital items, which will occur at the beginning of the year. Some of the store models, for example. We'll also invest in training associates to support that. And that'll put pressure on our profitability throughout the year, particularly as we -- so we'll try and scale that. So at the beginning of the year, our training will be smaller numbers of people. And to the extent that we see results from the training and staffing that we plan to invest in, we'll continue to invest in that throughout the year. So I'd say that the significance of those will depend on the success we see with the initiatives themselves.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: So is it fair to sort of characterize that the EPS growth isn't necessarily -- it's relatively consistent throughout the year?
componenttext: So is it fair to sort of characterize that the EPS growth isn't necessarily -- it's relatively consistent throughout the year?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we've given guidance for the first quarter and for the full year. And I'd expect that as we get into the year, we'll manage our results based on our usual practice of trying to maintain reasonable operating profit rates. And at the same time, invest
componenttext: Well, we've given guidance for the first quarter and for the full year. And I'd expect that as we get into the year, we'll manage our results based on our usual practice of trying to maintain reasonable operating profit rates. And at the same time, investing in the things that have proven successful that will drive our growth longer term.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010

componenttext: Yes, I mean I think North American Delivery trended up throughout the quarter. Not dramatically up, any particular month. And then if you look at North Market Retail, we're pretty flat. The comps were pretty flat throughout the quarter, 3%. And North American Delivery is minus one.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I got to talk about the quarter we're in, other than the guidance we gave, but I think its safe to say that we feel good about our existing customers buying more. We're continuing to kind of gain customers at about the current rate that we had been
componenttext: Well, I got to talk about the quarter we're in, other than the guidance we gave, but I think its safe to say that we feel good about our existing customers buying more. We're continuing to kind of gain customers at about the current rate that we had been gaining customers. But there is some kind of optimism that maybe the economy is helping us a little bit with existing customers. I don't -- Joe, do you want to add anything to that?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: All the difference you saw in the improvement, you saw sequentially. From Q3 to Q4 was existing customers strengthening in terms of their buying, as you indicated, Ron. Our acquisition of new customers continues to outpace lost customers. But the sequenti
componenttext: All the difference you saw in the improvement, you saw sequentially. From Q3 to Q4 was existing customers strengthening in terms of their buying, as you indicated, Ron. Our acquisition of new customers continues to outpace lost customers. But the sequential improvement that we saw about 1,000 basis points from Q3 to Q4 was driven most heavily by sales from existing customers strengthening.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ron, the synergies of cumulate [ph] $300 million, I think formerly, you said, I think the other 40% of it are call it cumulatively 80% in what will be 2010 here. Is that within your earnings guidance for 2010? Is that the number you've got baked in about
componenttext: Ron, the synergies of cumulate [ph] $300 million, I think formerly, you said, I think the other 40% of it are call it cumulatively 80% in what will be 2010 here. Is that within your earnings guidance for 2010? Is that the number you've got baked in about 80% of $300 million?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Mar 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's the number we've assumed. The $300 million with 40% coming year one. Another 40% coming in year two and then the last 20% in Q3. We feel pretty comfortable with that number.
componenttext: That's the number we've assumed. The $300 million with 40% coming year one. Another 40% coming in year two and then the last 20% in Q3. We feel pretty comfortable with that number.
