headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, we've said, we received stronger cash flow in the second half of the year. So after we get through the period where we're building inventory for the back-to-school period, we'd expect to address our share buyback program. And assuming cash flows
componenttext: I guess, we've said, we received stronger cash flow in the second half of the year. So after we get through the period where we're building inventory for the back-to-school period, we'd expect to address our share buyback program. And assuming cash flows remain strong and nothing untowards happens, we'd expect to rebegin our share buyback program sometime towards the middle of the year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if we look at your -- could you go into a bit more detail? Like you mentioned, obviously, you're seeing very, very nice results, and it was a nice quarter because of the integration, but the offset is that you're seeing weakness in the Retail side, an
componenttext: And if we look at your -- could you go into a bit more detail? Like you mentioned, obviously, you're seeing very, very nice results, and it was a nice quarter because of the integration, but the offset is that you're seeing weakness in the Retail side, and the currency will stop being in your favor, going forward. So how should we be thinking about it as the year progresses? And have you readjusted your goals for Europe, given the weakness you've seen in some of the retail areas, and obviously, the weakness we see every day on television?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Why don't I answer the math question first, and then Mike can talk about the operations. And I guess the math question is the impact of the euro. Strictly speaking, we expect that about 10% of our earnings are driven in the euro, so a 10% shift in the val
componenttext: Why don't I answer the math question first, and then Mike can talk about the operations. And I guess the math question is the impact of the euro. Strictly speaking, we expect that about 10% of our earnings are driven in the euro, so a 10% shift in the value of the euro would impact earnings by about $0.01 a share. That'll be a little bit offset by the strength in the Canadian and the Australian dollar. But obviously, to the extent that the decline in euro or troubles in the European market affect the world economy, that would have a different impact. Mike, why don't you?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to the operations there, Gary, the story for us in Europe this year is going to be about improving our margins and less about the top line growth. Clearly, we've got some work to do on the Retail side. And although we saw improvements in most
componenttext: With respect to the operations there, Gary, the story for us in Europe this year is going to be about improving our margins and less about the top line growth. Clearly, we've got some work to do on the Retail side. And although we saw improvements in most of the retail markets that we're in, in terms of comps in Q1, we're still not driving traffic the way we do in North America with really good office product offers to business customers. It's been much more price item on technology, and we need to get a better drumbeat of sort of the ink and paper offers and ink and paper traffic. But with respect to the business overall, I think that the plans that we've got to drive margin improvements, which I think you're seeing the results of in the first quarter, we're going to carry on throughout the course of the year. And so we expect, absent John's potential scenario of a real impact to the overall economy from this euro weakness, we expect all of those plans to carry through and to have strong margin improvement and profit improvement in Europe this year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one follow-up, and then I'll get off. Ron, could you talk about your thoughts on the small business customer right now? Like, obviously, you haven't seen the strength you want to see, but you actually had some pretty good BSD (sic) [SBD] [Staples Bus
componenttext: Just one follow-up, and then I'll get off. Ron, could you talk about your thoughts on the small business customer right now? Like, obviously, you haven't seen the strength you want to see, but you actually had some pretty good BSD (sic) [SBD] [Staples Business Delivery] here in North American Delivery numbers. Are you seeing any indications that they are starting to come back? Or are they still waiting because they're worried about the economy and worried about Washington?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Gary, I think they are coming back. And I think, again, I'm not an economist, but I am kind of optimistic about the economic recovery that we're starting to see. Our business is coming back just like it did in the last recession, and I think that bodes ve
componenttext: Gary, I think they are coming back. And I think, again, I'm not an economist, but I am kind of optimistic about the economic recovery that we're starting to see. Our business is coming back just like it did in the last recession, and I think that bodes very well for the company in 2010, 2011, 2012. Obviously, the economic indicators are really mixed, and we're seeing, in the first quarter, some choppy sales, kind of up and down. But from my perspective, the key is job creation. And our job is take care of customers, invest appropriately, run a tight ship, but there's some real positive signs we're seeing, I mean, the mix of off-contract to on-contract in our Contract business. Our Contract business is starting to see some momentum, and we're seeing that not only in the medium business side but the large business side. Customer counts are strong in our Retail business. Our SBD business continued to show some improvement during the quarter. So I'm not sure it's going to be a big-time recovery, but I think it's going to be a slow, steady recovery. Obviously, there's going to be some chops in the middle, but I'm a little more optimistic than I've been, maybe, the last few quarters.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Brad Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Market (sic) [KeyBanc Capital Markets].
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Brad Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Market (sic) [KeyBanc Capital Markets].

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just talk a little bit more about the margin expansion in North American Delivery. It seems like a lot of things working well for you there. Could you just talk a little bit more about how much of that is coming from Corporate Express and some
componenttext: I wanted to just talk a little bit more about the margin expansion in North American Delivery. It seems like a lot of things working well for you there. Could you just talk a little bit more about how much of that is coming from Corporate Express and some of the levers that you're pulling versus changes in the economic backdrop, like the off-contract sales coming back?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say -- I'll ask Joe Doody to answer that, but I would say it's more of what we're doing. Obviously, sales cures a lot of ills, but I think we've done a really nice job of running our business better and tighter. And, Joe, do you want to?
componenttext: I would say -- I'll ask Joe Doody to answer that, but I would say it's more of what we're doing. Obviously, sales cures a lot of ills, but I think we've done a really nice job of running our business better and tighter. And, Joe, do you want to?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's fair to say I'm very proud of the NAD team, because we've obviously got a lot of activity going on in the integration that's yielding some good savings for us. But at the same time, it's a lot of heavy lifting in the short term, especial
componenttext: Yes, I think it's fair to say I'm very proud of the NAD team, because we've obviously got a lot of activity going on in the integration that's yielding some good savings for us. But at the same time, it's a lot of heavy lifting in the short term, especially in the supply chain area. But it's across the board, Brad, in terms of good margin expansion, good benefits from sales force that we've seen and G&A and there's just all areas of the business. And as Ron said, the off-contract and the mix is improving. That's helping as well. And a little bit of volume growth as well.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And frankly, the pretty tough quarter a year ago, just to be honest.
componenttext: And frankly, the pretty tough quarter a year ago, just to be honest.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, John, you had mentioned one of the elements helping you to drive expense leverage was lower marketing. Could you just talk a little bit more about your plans for marketing going forward and ability to continue to get leverage there?
componenttext: And then, John, you had mentioned one of the elements helping you to drive expense leverage was lower marketing. Could you just talk a little bit more about your plans for marketing going forward and ability to continue to get leverage there?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think that one of the hallmarks of our entire marketing program is that it's performance based. So we try and take a look at metrics like sales per marketing dollar, and measure all of our programs on how productive they are. We test and we measur
componenttext: Sure. I think that one of the hallmarks of our entire marketing program is that it's performance based. So we try and take a look at metrics like sales per marketing dollar, and measure all of our programs on how productive they are. We test and we measure. And programs that work, we try to invest more in, and programs that don't, we invest less in. And that allows us to maintain a marketing spend that we think remains very productive and keeps us in the game, and yet has the ability to maintain the same relationship to sales that it does historically. And I think that's true, whether it's one of our Direct Marketing businesses or whether it's some of the things that we do in U.S. Retail that may be more branding, for example, with the TV programs.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of David Strasser with Janney Montgomery.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of David Strasser with Janney Montgomery.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to kind of talk a little bit about gross margin in the Retail business. You managed, despite the higher mix in PCs, to maintain a flat gross margin there. What were the offsetting factors to the negative mix that helped you there? And do you thin
componenttext: I wanted to kind of talk a little bit about gross margin in the Retail business. You managed, despite the higher mix in PCs, to maintain a flat gross margin there. What were the offsetting factors to the negative mix that helped you there? And do you think it's sustainable going forward, if that mix continues to go in that direction?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Demos is here. So let me ask Demos to talk about some of his growth in the high-margin businesses.
componenttext: Yes. Demos is here. So let me ask Demos to talk about some of his growth in the high-margin businesses.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Good morning, David. Well, first of all, on the low-margin businesses like computers, we are very focused on not only managing the inventory very carefully, getting it out to the right stores at the right time and really just paying close attention
componenttext: Sure. Good morning, David. Well, first of all, on the low-margin businesses like computers, we are very focused on not only managing the inventory very carefully, getting it out to the right stores at the right time and really just paying close attention to that so that we are selling the product earlier in the life cycle and not getting stuck with a dated product, but also in the stores really have focused a lot of effort, a lot of energy on training our associates, really putting the right people on the floor at the right time and really selling a complete solution to the customer and doing a much better job with that than, I think, we've done in the past. As we've mentioned, there are a lot of other highlights on the supply, the core supplies part of the business, which we continue to pay a lot of attention to. That's the heritage core business, and it's important to us. So I think we continue to work to innovate in-store displays, start creating excitement in the store, really have good meaningful promotions that are going to drive both customer traffic into the store and also move some of the categories we've mentioned. Categories such as dated, business essentials and, of course, ink and paper. So I think those have had a good impact on offsetting the core tech. And the last thing I should mention is our continued hard work on growing the services business, both on the tech repair, EasyTech business, as well as Copy & Print.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. As a follow-up to that, when you do sell a full solution system to a consumer, how significant is the difference in margin versus the rest of the business? I mean, can you get it relatively close when you're on top of your game on the t
componenttext: I appreciate that. As a follow-up to that, when you do sell a full solution system to a consumer, how significant is the difference in margin versus the rest of the business? I mean, can you get it relatively close when you're on top of your game on the technology side?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we can. I think it's challenging because we start out at a very low point, and the idea is not to -- it would be great to match the margin of the house, but that's probably not very realistic, so we just want to make every sale a meaningful one. A
componenttext: I think we can. I think it's challenging because we start out at a very low point, and the idea is not to -- it would be great to match the margin of the house, but that's probably not very realistic, so we just want to make every sale a meaningful one. And I think taking time out to really listen to customers and do a very good job attaching the things they need, the software they need, anti-virus, all of that makes a fairly meaningful difference. It makes it worthwhile for us to pursue this.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the Service business is at -- are you kind of at your plan, above plan? And are you seeing it more as helping you sell other parts of the business or as a profit center on its own?
componenttext: And the Service business is at -- are you kind of at your plan, above plan? And are you seeing it more as helping you sell other parts of the business or as a profit center on its own?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Tech business provides both, actually. It's a great business to have. When selling a computer, customers really need peace of mind. And when they buy a PC, it's very important for them to meet our tech repair person who's right there, and they can gain th
componenttext: Tech business provides both, actually. It's a great business to have. When selling a computer, customers really need peace of mind. And when they buy a PC, it's very important for them to meet our tech repair person who's right there, and they can gain the trust and confidence that if something should go wrong, they can come back to the store. And then as a standalone business, it's got a very good profitable model. So from a break-fix or an upgrade-cycle standpoint, people can come in and get what they need with a fairly quick turnaround. And it's exciting that we now have trained associates in every single store throughout the U.S. and Canada and continue to add more training to that. So I think it's going to continue to just keep getting better.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Kate McShane with Citi Investments.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Kate McShane with Citi Investments.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give any additional commentary on the North American Retail comps? You had mentioned that the comp reflected increase to customer traffic, but a lower average order size, which is the opposite, I think, of what most companies have stated this quar
componenttext: Can you give any additional commentary on the North American Retail comps? You had mentioned that the comp reflected increase to customer traffic, but a lower average order size, which is the opposite, I think, of what most companies have stated this quarter. So any insight into exactly what's driving traffic that may have improved quarter-over-quarter?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we're happy with the customer count increase of roughly 3%. That's a good news. I think the one thing that we probably want a little bit different is the sort of composition of that number. That number is driven primarily by consumers and a little bit
componenttext: So we're happy with the customer count increase of roughly 3%. That's a good news. I think the one thing that we probably want a little bit different is the sort of composition of that number. That number is driven primarily by consumers and a little bit less of the small business customers. So although we're getting the small business customer back, we're getting the consumer back faster. I think a lot of our good promotions and incentives that we've put out there have really driven the traffic back to the store. And I think a lot of the traditional non-office supply jobs-related retailers have seen that increase over the past couple of months, as they've reported in their number. So I think that probably helps us get at why the number is higher, and the AOV [average order value] number is slightly lower. So we continue to see tech prices go through that normal cycle of more features, slightly less retail. And we'll just keep working on driving the traffic and building the average order. So not exactly the perfect mix, but good and improving.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: One last question for Ron. You definitely sounded more optimistic from when you last gave guidance in March, but guidance is basically remaining unchanged for the year. I guess it's $0.02 a little higher on the lower end. I'm just trying to gauge how much
componenttext: One last question for Ron. You definitely sounded more optimistic from when you last gave guidance in March, but guidance is basically remaining unchanged for the year. I guess it's $0.02 a little higher on the lower end. I'm just trying to gauge how much of this is an effort to be conservative or does this mean that you haven't seen much more of an improvement than when you first gave guidance in March for this year?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not quite sure how to answer that question, Kate, but am I a bit more optimistic than I was last quarter? I am. I think we do want to be conservative in our guidance for the year. I think we've said that if things get better, will be at the high end.
componenttext: I'm not quite sure how to answer that question, Kate, but am I a bit more optimistic than I was last quarter? I am. I think we do want to be conservative in our guidance for the year. I think we've said that if things get better, will be at the high end. If things don't continue in the direction they're heading, we could be somewhere in the middle. So I think we do want to be conservative. I'd much rather underpromise and overdeliver rather than the other way around, but I think we have reflected the fact that our first quarter was pretty good. We've taken up the bottom side of the guidance by $0.02, and I hope to be able to do that every quarter this year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Kate, if I could just add to that. I think I mentioned that we do see a relatively slow rate of job growth in the economy overall, which is going to be significant to us, for us to be able to sustain faster revenue growth. So we've talked about low single
componenttext: Kate, if I could just add to that. I think I mentioned that we do see a relatively slow rate of job growth in the economy overall, which is going to be significant to us, for us to be able to sustain faster revenue growth. So we've talked about low single-digit revenue growth throughout the year. If we see faster growth than that, that would be positive. But of the indicators we track, we don't see job growth as accelerating in a rate that would warrant extreme optimism about the back half of the year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, betting on the economy, and it's hard to do that.
componenttext: Yes, betting on the economy, and it's hard to do that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, you talked about the upcoming, I guess, the next stage of the Corporate Express integration in the U.S., which will really focus on supply chain. Can you talk about what you learned in Orlando and Kansas City? What you think the benefits to
componenttext: First of all, you talked about the upcoming, I guess, the next stage of the Corporate Express integration in the U.S., which will really focus on supply chain. Can you talk about what you learned in Orlando and Kansas City? What you think the benefits to the cost structure and to working capital might be? Let me just ask the second question, get it out of the way. Mike, you gave us some interesting break-outs of the composition of the International P&L, speaking specifically about the delta in Europe, which exceeded the delta or the improvement that you saw overall in International. If you can talk about the other components of the International P&L and put those in context would be very helpful.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Matt, on the integrations, as you noted, we've got a couple of quad channel buildings under our belt, to Kansas City, most recently, Orlando. We have a few more scheduled here shortly of this year. What we've learned, one, is it's not easy. They're each a
componenttext: Matt, on the integrations, as you noted, we've got a couple of quad channel buildings under our belt, to Kansas City, most recently, Orlando. We have a few more scheduled here shortly of this year. What we've learned, one, is it's not easy. They're each a little bit unique, because there are a different local activities that have gone on in each of the buildings, from Corporate Express standpoint, that we have to take into account when we are bringing them on board. So it's a little bit more upfront work in each and every one of them. So that's what we've learned. But as far as the benefits that we're achieving both in terms of costs and inventory, et cetera, is just meeting the levels that we anticipated. So we continue to have a year of heavy lifting, not only in terms of the integration of the quad channel buildings, but also of the many delivery hubs that we are in the process of integrating as well throughout the network, to get a single delivery in a geography, consolidated between a Corporate Express suite and the Staples suite. So a lot of work being done throughout the rest of this year, achieving the benefits that we anticipated. A little bit more upfront work than we anticipate going into each of the different markets.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And, Matt, on the other components of the International P&L, the Printing Services division, as I mentioned, had a tough quarter. Their sales were down a little over 20%, and that impacted our overall profitability by about 80 basis points. As I mentioned
componenttext: And, Matt, on the other components of the International P&L, the Printing Services division, as I mentioned, had a tough quarter. Their sales were down a little over 20%, and that impacted our overall profitability by about 80 basis points. As I mentioned, we've implemented significant headcount reductions in that business, and sales have stabilized there. So we expect that business to be profit neutral for the rest of the year, which will be a nice upside over 2009 losses. China is the other big factor for us. As you know, we lost about $50 million in Asia in 2009. We're kind of in the three-step process of improving that. One is kind of back to basics, getting out of the unprofitable businesses we're in and anniversary-ing some of the onetime costs, and that's going to kick in, in the second and third quarters of this year. And then building the business, improving the gross margins there to a better merchandising and, ultimately, building scale there. But for us in China, Q1 was about the same as Q1 was a year ago. The improvements that we expect there for the P&L will be more in the last three quarters of the year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, Mike, given what you see currently from, I guess, printing in China, in particular, since that seems to be the biggest drag. At what point do you cycle the issues there? And do they start to, I guess, together become neutral or perhaps even contribute
componenttext: So, Mike, given what you see currently from, I guess, printing in China, in particular, since that seems to be the biggest drag. At what point do you cycle the issues there? And do they start to, I guess, together become neutral or perhaps even contribute year-on-year to the P&L?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: They should start to be positive, at least on a year-over-year comparisons, beginning in the second quarter.
componenttext: They should start to be positive, at least on a year-over-year comparisons, beginning in the second quarter.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Horvers with JPMorgan.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Chris Horvers with JPMorgan.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you talk about the -- I want to dig on the off-contract purchasing behavior a bit more, some color on what you're seeing there, perhaps what the customers are buying compared to what they weren't buying a year ago. And if that was, potentially, maybe
componenttext: Can you talk about the -- I want to dig on the off-contract purchasing behavior a bit more, some color on what you're seeing there, perhaps what the customers are buying compared to what they weren't buying a year ago. And if that was, potentially, maybe a flurry, once those new budgets got but got were put in place and it slowed down, or are you seeing some encouraging consistency?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not a flurry, Chris, pretty much more consistent improvement there on a month-over-month, quarter-over-quarter basis. And we're just seeing a little bit of relaxation on the part of some of our customers, in terms of allowing people to buy the more discre
componenttext: Not a flurry, Chris, pretty much more consistent improvement there on a month-over-month, quarter-over-quarter basis. And we're just seeing a little bit of relaxation on the part of some of our customers, in terms of allowing people to buy the more discretionary products. So an example of that would be our Furniture business is just slightly negative now, a year ago it was down between 20% and 30%. So it's not a built-up demand. It's been a pretty consistent improvement.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Would you regard that furniture is the most discretionary portion on the off-contract side?
componenttext: Would you regard that furniture is the most discretionary portion on the off-contract side?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's either on the customer's contract or it's off, it varies by customers. So it depends on how the customer defines what's on their contract and what's not. But certainly, furniture is the one category that's probably the most consistently off contract
componenttext: It's either on the customer's contract or it's off, it varies by customers. So it depends on how the customer defines what's on their contract and what's not. But certainly, furniture is the one category that's probably the most consistently off contract for a customer. But it does vary by each and every customer's definition.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to give you some numbers, Chris, the impact of that off-contract, On-Contract thing, I mean, a year ago, Q1 of '09, it was impacting our gross margin in NAD about 50 basis points negative. Second quarter was 30 points negative. Third quarter was 20 p
componenttext: Just to give you some numbers, Chris, the impact of that off-contract, On-Contract thing, I mean, a year ago, Q1 of '09, it was impacting our gross margin in NAD about 50 basis points negative. Second quarter was 30 points negative. Third quarter was 20 points negative. Fourth quarter, as we announced last quarter, was minus 10. And then this quarter, plus 10. So I think it's kind of a trend more than a blip.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the only other final point I'd make on it, Chris, is that when you compare where we are this quarter versus a year ago, as we said, it's an improvement versus two years ago, first quarter of '08, it's still significantly lower.
componenttext: And the only other final point I'd make on it, Chris, is that when you compare where we are this quarter versus a year ago, as we said, it's an improvement versus two years ago, first quarter of '08, it's still significantly lower.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is that on a two-year trend as we all like to look at? Is that improving?
componenttext: Is that on a two-year trend as we all like to look at? Is that improving?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't have that right in front of me, so I can't answer that or you.
componenttext: I don't have that right in front of me, so I can't answer that or you.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then any commentary on what's going on in the Quill business?
componenttext: And then any commentary on what's going on in the Quill business?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Quill business is improving. So it got better as all of our businesses did on a trend basis. We like the trends there. It's an awareness-building activity that we really need to drive with Quill. They've got a great brand, customers that they servic
componenttext: Well, Quill business is improving. So it got better as all of our businesses did on a trend basis. We like the trends there. It's an awareness-building activity that we really need to drive with Quill. They've got a great brand, customers that they service, they service better than anyone else, extremely high customer satisfaction therefore extremely high retention. It's all about acquisition in there, it's about awareness. So those are the things we have to do to drive that business to a positive comp growth.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Mitch Kaiser with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Mitch Kaiser with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you'd talk a little bit, I know you've made a lot of investments on the services side of the business and the EasyTech. Could you just help us think about the expenses as they ripple throughout the year and maybe some of the benefits, certain
componenttext: I was hoping you'd talk a little bit, I know you've made a lot of investments on the services side of the business and the EasyTech. Could you just help us think about the expenses as they ripple throughout the year and maybe some of the benefits, certainly they've shown up a little bit on the gross margin side as you talked about as you've expanded the tech?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll ask John Mahoney to address that one.
componenttext: I'll ask John Mahoney to address that one.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll talk about the investments we're making. We talked about the fact that they tend to scale with results. So whether it's some of the remodels that we're doing for both Copy & Print and for our tech offerings and stores, whether it's scale and labor a
componenttext: We'll talk about the investments we're making. We talked about the fact that they tend to scale with results. So whether it's some of the remodels that we're doing for both Copy & Print and for our tech offerings and stores, whether it's scale and labor and something like EasyTech or sales force in Copy & Print, we're able to pretty well scale those with the results. So although it deleverages our expenses, it isn't an unmanaged deleverage in our P&L. So the scope of that really depends on the success with having those is, as Demos described it, had decent success in growing our businesses that we're investing in faster than the rest of the house. And through a combination of better execution and an improving economy, we hope that, that will continue, and that will allow us to keep making those investments that will benefit the longer term, but not in a way that's going to dramatically adversely impact the current year P&L.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the real benefits in the utilization of the EasyTechs, I think, right? Is that how to think about that?
componenttext: So the real benefits in the utilization of the EasyTechs, I think, right? Is that how to think about that?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: There have been a lot of times, and I think that the issue is we've tested this for some time in both the remodels we're doing, which improves our tech sales. The Copy & Print remodels that we've done, which drive improvement in our Copy & Print sales gro
componenttext: There have been a lot of times, and I think that the issue is we've tested this for some time in both the remodels we're doing, which improves our tech sales. The Copy & Print remodels that we've done, which drive improvement in our Copy & Print sales growth. But they do scale. And EasyTech, for example in a store, isn't as productive as a mature EasyTech when they first start, and the same thing's true for many of the staff that we put in in the Copy & Print center. But we are able to see the productivity of each of those people grow in a way, that although it requires some expense deleverage in the near term, we're very confident that it's going to result in driving the profitability of the store, overall, in the case of Copy & Print and the Tech business and in some of the sales force changes we've made for the lines of business in NAD to improve and achieve some of our longer-term margin targets over time.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Mike, maybe, could you just talk a little bit about your exposure in Europe to the Government business? I'd probably should know that. But if you could just maybe refresh us on that and maybe what you're seeing there with the upcoming potential b
componenttext: And then Mike, maybe, could you just talk a little bit about your exposure in Europe to the Government business? I'd probably should know that. But if you could just maybe refresh us on that and maybe what you're seeing there with the upcoming potential budget cuts?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mitch, we don't have a huge Government business in Europe. So I think we're relatively limited to that, particularly if you think about the countries in Southern Europe that have been all grouped together as having real budget issues. We have not a lot of
componenttext: Mitch, we don't have a huge Government business in Europe. So I think we're relatively limited to that, particularly if you think about the countries in Southern Europe that have been all grouped together as having real budget issues. We have not a lot of Office Products business there in general and not a lot of Government business there. We have a little more Government business in Norway, but I think their economy is on a much more solid footing.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Colin McGranahan with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Colin McGranahan with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: First question, just on SG&A, you highlighted marketing expense, reduced marketing expense is the first driver in total. And I think you mentioned it in each of the divisions. Can you talk about whether that's a synergy saving, whether there's some change
componenttext: First question, just on SG&A, you highlighted marketing expense, reduced marketing expense is the first driver in total. And I think you mentioned it in each of the divisions. Can you talk about whether that's a synergy saving, whether there's some change in the marketing strategy or what's driving the lower expense and the leverage in marketing there?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's probably two things. One, it is the synergy savings because we're obviously integrating our business in Corporate Express, and there's a lot of duplicative marketing cost that have gone away. But I think the other thing is just this evol
componenttext: Yes, I think it's probably two things. One, it is the synergy savings because we're obviously integrating our business in Corporate Express, and there's a lot of duplicative marketing cost that have gone away. But I think the other thing is just this evolution of marketing from Sunday circulars and catalogs to more of an online marketing, which is a lot less expensive, and frankly, in most cases, equally effective. So I think it's both of those things. So I think it's really kind of a marketing trend. I don't think we've reduced our share of voice out there at all. In fact, our customer count trends would indicate that we're gaining share of customers. But I do think both of those things are big impacts on our business.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So you think that could be a little bit of a persistent source of leverage going forward?
componenttext: So you think that could be a little bit of a persistent source of leverage going forward?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think so.
componenttext: I think so.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, just on the key growth initiative. Obviously, it sounds like you had a little better Promo business than what we've seen for quite some time, breakroom. How much of that do you think is just the, a little bit better improvement in the d
componenttext: And then secondly, just on the key growth initiative. Obviously, it sounds like you had a little better Promo business than what we've seen for quite some time, breakroom. How much of that do you think is just the, a little bit better improvement in the discretionary spending versus -- have you been able to measure the impact of, say, the new websites and the training hours that have started to trickle in for your contract sales force?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe?
componenttext: Joe?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, well, first, on the promo, I'll tell you, that is not really an increase of broad base due to more discretionary spending there, Colin. We achieved one major new bit of business in that area, which heavily drove that growth that was indicated this qu
componenttext: Yes, well, first, on the promo, I'll tell you, that is not really an increase of broad base due to more discretionary spending there, Colin. We achieved one major new bit of business in that area, which heavily drove that growth that was indicated this quarter. So that was more of a onetime major bid win. But broad based, the promo area is still not seeing an increase due to companies loosening up the purse strings, if you will. On the facilities in breakroom, as we said, we've seen our growth above the house there. That's in dollars. In units, it's much higher than that because we've made some pricing moves to get us more as a destination category there and viewed as such, not a convenience category. And we're clearly ramping up on the sales force, a lot of cross-selling activities going on. A lot of good early successes there, but it's still early. We are quite confident that, that growth initiative is going to yield significant growth opportunities for us in the many, many years to come.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just one final follow up for John. We're talking politics, so handicapping odds is always a question. But how confident are you that legislation will pass to return your tax rate back to the 34.5% range?
componenttext: And then just one final follow up for John. We're talking politics, so handicapping odds is always a question. But how confident are you that legislation will pass to return your tax rate back to the 34.5% range?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're right. We've made a strong effort to avoid handicapping any politics. I can give you a couple of facts. The bill that would extend these tax provisions has passed both the House and the Senate and in reconciliation right now. And there's some reaso
componenttext: You're right. We've made a strong effort to avoid handicapping any politics. I can give you a couple of facts. The bill that would extend these tax provisions has passed both the House and the Senate and in reconciliation right now. And there's some reason to think that Congress had some sense of urgency about it. I mean, we've got relatively arcane international tax allocation elements of the bill. Probably, the one that's got the most political close, the R&D tax credit. You'll notice some of the companies that are tech-oriented had similar bumps in their tax rate this quarter because they were unable to take the benefit, the R&D tax credit, which is a stimulus. So I guess without handicapping it, the facts would dictate that it would surprise us if it didn't pass some time during the year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And how's your cash tax rate comparing to your accrual tax rate at this point?
componenttext: And how's your cash tax rate comparing to your accrual tax rate at this point?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our cash tax rate is only slightly lower than the accrual tax rate. We don't have a huge number of timing differences.
componenttext: Our cash tax rate is only slightly lower than the accrual tax rate. We don't have a huge number of timing differences.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Michael Lasser with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Michael Lasser with Barclays Capital.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Turning back to an earlier discussion, aside from the currency impact, are you seeing any change as you look at the present trends in a rhythm of the business in Europe? Are you seeing any change from the events? And would you expect that to be an immedia
componenttext: Turning back to an earlier discussion, aside from the currency impact, are you seeing any change as you look at the present trends in a rhythm of the business in Europe? Are you seeing any change from the events? And would you expect that to be an immediate impact or might it take a little time for it to trickle through to have an impact which will maybe slow down some of the results there?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Michael, it's Mike Miles. We've had a nice gradual improvement in most of our European businesses over the last nine months. It has been, though, over that period of time, relatively choppy as it's come back. And so I don't want to try and read too much i
componenttext: Michael, it's Mike Miles. We've had a nice gradual improvement in most of our European businesses over the last nine months. It has been, though, over that period of time, relatively choppy as it's come back. And so I don't want to try and read too much into numbers one way or the other over the last two weeks since the Greek crisis has unfolded. As I said earlier, I think our story in Europe this year is more one of margin improvement as opposed to betting on a huge economic recovery. So absent something catastrophic, I think we're in pretty good shape for our plans for Europe this year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in the U.S. business, are you noticing any changes in the competitive pricing environment? And do you anticipate, as conditions continue to improve, that this could put some -- it could become a bit more intense?
componenttext: And then in the U.S. business, are you noticing any changes in the competitive pricing environment? And do you anticipate, as conditions continue to improve, that this could put some -- it could become a bit more intense?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are you talking about the Delivery business or...
componenttext: Are you talking about the Delivery business or...

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, more so on the delivery side than the retail side.
componenttext: Yes, more so on the delivery side than the retail side.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Delivery side, let me ask Joe to comment.
componenttext: Delivery side, let me ask Joe to comment.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, Michael, the market is always very competitive, but it continues to remain rationale. We continue to utilize our low-cost model to build sustainable profitable growth, and we're extremely satisfied with the level of acquisition and retentio
componenttext: Well, I think, Michael, the market is always very competitive, but it continues to remain rationale. We continue to utilize our low-cost model to build sustainable profitable growth, and we're extremely satisfied with the level of acquisition and retention that we're currently experiencing out there. In our margin expansion, I think that you're seeing in our strong profit margin, rates, I think is indicative of our continued pricing discipline, as well as the use of our low-cost structure. So we continue to be disciplined in going after new business and as well as all of our existing business. It's a competitive marketplace. We anticipate that that's going to continue.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, how did your Public Sector business do during the first quarter?
componenttext: Joe, how did your Public Sector business do during the first quarter?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's great. To be honest, the sales of government is not a significant part of our existing business. But we have certainly seen increased opportunity and willingness of states and municipalities to not just enter into a dialogue but to pursue business wi
componenttext: It's great. To be honest, the sales of government is not a significant part of our existing business. But we have certainly seen increased opportunity and willingness of states and municipalities to not just enter into a dialogue but to pursue business with us. We are investing and growing our sales force in that area and have been doing that. We continue to gain momentum there. So it's growing very nicely. We're extremely satisfied with that business.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Michael Baker with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Michael Baker with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple related questions, I guess, back to Europe. So your full year sales guidance is the same, at low-single digits. But have you changed what you think about that in terms of reducing your expectations for Europe given what's going on there? And I gu
componenttext: A couple related questions, I guess, back to Europe. So your full year sales guidance is the same, at low-single digits. But have you changed what you think about that in terms of reducing your expectations for Europe given what's going on there? And I guess a related question is you can talk a little bit more detail in terms of the trends in Europe since this Greek thing has started to unfold over the last couple of weeks, has business fall off at all in Europe? And I guess, while we're talking about trends, if you could just talk about the trends in the U.S. through the quarter? That would also be helpful.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Mike, you want to talk about Europe?
componenttext: Mike, you want to talk about Europe?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think as we look at Europe and think about the full year, and for us to achieve the guidance that we've got and our plans is kind of the key thing that needs to happen, and we're really looking at it as kind of our issue as opposed to the market.
componenttext: Sure. I think as we look at Europe and think about the full year, and for us to achieve the guidance that we've got and our plans is kind of the key thing that needs to happen, and we're really looking at it as kind of our issue as opposed to the market. The key thing that has to happen is we need to get our retail comps going again. As I mentioned, we made progress in most of the markets in Europe. The Netherlands was the one exception to that, but Germany and Portugal and the U.K. were all at least as good as Q4, and in most cases, stronger than we saw during 2009 and during Q4. So we're seeing a recovery. As I said before, I don't want to talk too much about the last couple of weeks in Europe because over the course of the last year, it's been very choppy, and I wouldn't want to read anything into the numbers that we're seeing week-to-week there. But for us, turning the comps around, which I think is about getting, as I said, the business customer buying office supplies from us. And that's the key challenge for us with European sales.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Michael, I think John tried to address the currency issue. I mean, we do probably have a stronger currency in places like Canada and Australia in the event we'll see lower currency in Europe. In terms of last quarter, I think we've said the business w
componenttext: And Michael, I think John tried to address the currency issue. I mean, we do probably have a stronger currency in places like Canada and Australia in the event we'll see lower currency in Europe. In terms of last quarter, I think we've said the business was a little choppy, but April was our best comping quarter or comping period in our Retail business. So we saw some good success in April.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could just follow up though one more time, just more specifically, again, your total sales number is low-single digits for your guidance, it's the same as it was. And I imagine you doubled [ph] up U.S. delivery international. Have the components of t
componenttext: If I could just follow up though one more time, just more specifically, again, your total sales number is low-single digits for your guidance, it's the same as it was. And I imagine you doubled [ph] up U.S. delivery international. Have the components of that low single-digit guidance changed today versus when you talked about guidance in the fourth quarter?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think so. It's probably a level of precision that I'm not perfectly able to answer. But I think in general, we feel kind of similarly about the growth trajectories of each of our three businesses as we did three months ago.
componenttext: I don't think so. It's probably a level of precision that I'm not perfectly able to answer. But I think in general, we feel kind of similarly about the growth trajectories of each of our three businesses as we did three months ago.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Dan Binder with Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Dan Binder with Jefferies.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a question on your ability to get the average order size up particularly in Corporate Express. I was wondering if you could give us an update on where that gap is today and the progress you've been able to make?
componenttext: Just a question on your ability to get the average order size up particularly in Corporate Express. I was wondering if you could give us an update on where that gap is today and the progress you've been able to make?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's still a gap there but then the business is becoming so integrated. We're really looking at our overall combined Staples and Corporate Express results to track our improvements. So we're not just looking at improving the former CE base, but al
componenttext: Yes, there's still a gap there but then the business is becoming so integrated. We're really looking at our overall combined Staples and Corporate Express results to track our improvements. So we're not just looking at improving the former CE base, but also always looking to drive the Staples base as well. So we're around $200 combined. It was up about $7. We had a several hundred basis points improvement and reduction of our small orders. So it is something that our sales team in Contract is driving on an everyday basis in their workings with our customers and providing incentives to them as well as incentives to our customers to drive that behavior, and we're extremely satisfied. It's a slow and steady improvement.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then a follow up on the Corporate Express side of it, recognizing you've had it for a while now and it's maybe a little bit harder to discern the differences. Just curious, are we now through sort of that period where there's an attrition from the cha
componenttext: And then a follow up on the Corporate Express side of it, recognizing you've had it for a while now and it's maybe a little bit harder to discern the differences. Just curious, are we now through sort of that period where there's an attrition from the change, you'd probably built something in at the outset for some attrition of those accounts. Just curious if there's still any pressure there.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, pressure there is to perform many changes to the customers pretty flawlessly. So we talked about the fact that we're making infrastructure changes out there, closing down buildings, consolidating volume into different buildings. We've got to pull th
componenttext: Well, pressure there is to perform many changes to the customers pretty flawlessly. So we talked about the fact that we're making infrastructure changes out there, closing down buildings, consolidating volume into different buildings. We've got to pull that off flawlessly so that it's not seen by the customers. If we don't, then there's certainly risk, not only to our CE customers but to our Staples legacy customers. So we're going to continue to go through more changes for our customers. Our delivery drivers will change for many and most of our customers as we consolidate suite together in geographies. So we've got to do everything we can to minimize the disruption to the customer. We also mentioned the fact that we're working on a new e-commerce site that will be used for both our Staples legacy and our CE customers. Converting customers to that site when that becomes available is another change. And again, we've got to just pull those all off flawlessly. But so far, I think many are extremely satisfied, as I said, with our level of retention, not only among our existing Staples legacy customers but also our former CE customers.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Joe Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Joe Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Any commentary on the regional trends here in the U.S. and what you're seeing?
componenttext: Any commentary on the regional trends here in the U.S. and what you're seeing?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're really seeing broad-based kind of improvement across the country and across all regions. We sliced it and diced it, but there's really not much difference throughout the country.
componenttext: We're really seeing broad-based kind of improvement across the country and across all regions. We sliced it and diced it, but there's really not much difference throughout the country.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just another follow-up on Europe. How much of the weakness that you've experienced, I guess at least in this quarter and as of late, just relates do you think to sort of rebuilding that brand especially as you put together the Corporate Express w
componenttext: And then just another follow-up on Europe. How much of the weakness that you've experienced, I guess at least in this quarter and as of late, just relates do you think to sort of rebuilding that brand especially as you put together the Corporate Express with Staples versus the macro pressure that is obviously happening over there?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe, it's Mike. I think it's virtually all of the macro pressure. I don't think we're suffering anything for the transition of the brand from Corporate Express to Staples. In fact, in Norway, small geography, a limited number of stores, but we changed all
componenttext: Joe, it's Mike. I think it's virtually all of the macro pressure. I don't think we're suffering anything for the transition of the brand from Corporate Express to Staples. In fact, in Norway, small geography, a limited number of stores, but we changed all the stores there from the banner indurs, which was what they were called under Corporate Express to Staples in the first quarter, and we have 3% comp sales growth there which was by far the best performance we had in our European retail. In most cases, Corporate Express didn't have a great strong brand in Europe. So the change has been relatively a non-event for most customers. There are a few Staples legacy brands in Europe like JPG and MondOffice in the catalog space that do have very strong brand names and heritage. And we're going to be more gradual about our transition there. So I think most of the issues that we've seen in Europe have been economic, and hopefully as the economy recovers, so will our sales.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the gross margin, obviously, it was pretty solid this quarter. I understand what the drivers are. And we were just kind of thinking, of those drivers, what do you think is sustainable going forward? I would bet that it's still early innings in terms of
componenttext: On the gross margin, obviously, it was pretty solid this quarter. I understand what the drivers are. And we were just kind of thinking, of those drivers, what do you think is sustainable going forward? I would bet that it's still early innings in terms of the synergies that you're realizing and the buying power. But if you could maybe talk about that a little bit more?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: John?
componenttext: John?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that in each of the businesses, they've got their own margin characteristics. In international, for example, we've talked about the buying synergies coming in later than they had in the U.S. And so that's one of the big drivers in Europe. In
componenttext: Well, I think that in each of the businesses, they've got their own margin characteristics. In international, for example, we've talked about the buying synergies coming in later than they had in the U.S. And so that's one of the big drivers in Europe. In NAD, the improvements we've seen over the last 18 months in distribution and delivery have had a dramatic impact, seeing some pressure more recently with some of the elements of transportation. But overall, NAD, through a combination of gaining the average order size up in the Contract business, driving the mix in SPD and getting the order size up at Quill all have driven gross margin there and all those things are sustainable. In North American Retail, part of the biggest issue there is mix. And as Demos talked about, driving improvements or faster growth in some of the high-margin Service businesses, improving attachment rate in the Tech business all helped. So each of them has their own story but it isn't one-dimensional, any of the business units. Each of them have a number of initiatives they're working on all of which should allow us to continue to see gross margin improvement.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of William Truelove with UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of William Truelove with UBS.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could talk a little bit about the strong customer acquisition in North American Delivery. Is it coming from new businesses? Are you acquiring customers from the independents or from say the other big-box retailers in that area?
componenttext: I was hoping you could talk a little bit about the strong customer acquisition in North American Delivery. Is it coming from new businesses? Are you acquiring customers from the independents or from say the other big-box retailers in that area?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Joe?
componenttext: Joe?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: All the above. I think it's clearly, it's both mid-volume, mid-market as well as some large customer base. You've got all situations where you've got customers, in some cases, limited, but still some that are consolidating programs for the first time. Oth
componenttext: All the above. I think it's clearly, it's both mid-volume, mid-market as well as some large customer base. You've got all situations where you've got customers, in some cases, limited, but still some that are consolidating programs for the first time. Others that are just a competitive win in the marketplace. So it really comes in all sizes and flavors.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to give you a little color commentary in the first quarter, our sales from existing accounts were kind of flattish from last quarter. Our lost accounts went way down. Our sales from new customers went up, and our line of business customers also went
componenttext: Just to give you a little color commentary in the first quarter, our sales from existing accounts were kind of flattish from last quarter. Our lost accounts went way down. Our sales from new customers went up, and our line of business customers also went up. So just kind of gives you a sense for what made up the number.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Alan Rifkin with Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Alan Rifkin with Bank of America.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I had one for you, Ron. I think in hindsight, we can certainly see your recent precaution in terms of greater share buybacks on the prior conference call. Now that we've been able to quantify the incremental investment in Australia, and you said that you
componenttext: I had one for you, Ron. I think in hindsight, we can certainly see your recent precaution in terms of greater share buybacks on the prior conference call. Now that we've been able to quantify the incremental investment in Australia, and you said that you are looking for strong cash flow in the second half. Could you maybe just shed a little bit more color on and realizing that obviously the environment is still difficult, but could you maybe just shed a little bit more color on the hesitancy at this point to commit to some share buy backs throughout the remainder of the year if your cash flow does continue to improve?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't think we're hesitant at all. I think, first of all, it's not my decision. It's our board's direction that will determine whether we do buybacks or not. But we wanted to make an investment in Australia, and I think we've allotted money to do t
componenttext: Yes, I don't think we're hesitant at all. I think, first of all, it's not my decision. It's our board's direction that will determine whether we do buybacks or not. But we wanted to make an investment in Australia, and I think we've allotted money to do that. We've wanted to, obviously, do the inventory build for Back to School and that's really the story in the second quarter, and you're right. In the third and fourth quarter, we hope and expect that the cash flows are going to be stronger. And I think at that point, we'd be willing to consider buying back stock. I think we already have an authorization out there. I think we've probably got close to $1 billion left in the pre-existing authorization. So no, I don't think it's an unreasonable question. I think it's one that our board will consider at our next meeting.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hypothetically, if the cash flows do come in over and above your plan for the year, would it be reasonable to expect that the incremental cash flow would be used for share buyback as opposed to further incremental investment?
componenttext: Hypothetically, if the cash flows do come in over and above your plan for the year, would it be reasonable to expect that the incremental cash flow would be used for share buyback as opposed to further incremental investment?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I hate dealing with hypotheticals. So it's hard for me to kind of give a sound like that kind of commits us to anything at this point.
componenttext: Yes, I hate dealing with hypotheticals. So it's hard for me to kind of give a sound like that kind of commits us to anything at this point.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our final question today is from the line of Stephen Chick with FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our final question today is from the line of Stephen Chick with FBR Capital Markets.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just two questions, and the first is related or another question on North American Delivery margins. And if I look at it, it was a very good quarter. It looks like company earnings in that segment were up $43 million year-over-year, really close to the le
componenttext: Just two questions, and the first is related or another question on North American Delivery margins. And if I look at it, it was a very good quarter. It looks like company earnings in that segment were up $43 million year-over-year, really close to the level of sales. And so on an incremental basis, it's nearly 100%. It sounds like margins were up in the Delivery business, and I know there's some synergies. But maybe for Joe, as we look forward, can you speak a little bit to what the, say fixed versus variable costs are for North American Delivery and how we can think about incremental margin and margin expansion as we head through the rest of the year here?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe I'll just comment first and then Joe can pitch in afterwards. Our expenses change in terms of whether they're fixed or variable depending on -- within our planning ranges. So there are a lot of moving parts in a big business like Joe's that drive th
componenttext: Maybe I'll just comment first and then Joe can pitch in afterwards. Our expenses change in terms of whether they're fixed or variable depending on -- within our planning ranges. So there are a lot of moving parts in a big business like Joe's that drive the flow through. Obviously, we don't expect to see 100% flow through on sales dollars going forward. Ron mentioned that we had a relatively easy compare in NAD with last year's first quarter in terms of the operating margin rate. But I think we're looking for over the long-term, steady improvement in the operating margin of NAD towards our long-term targets. And we're not going to see that in a linear fashion exactly the same way in every quarter.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And thank you for nosing that contribution in the quarter, Stephen. But as John said, I think we've got a lot of activities that are driving to achieve our long-term goal. We're not going to see that type of quarterly improvement consistently moving out t
componenttext: And thank you for nosing that contribution in the quarter, Stephen. But as John said, I think we've got a lot of activities that are driving to achieve our long-term goal. We're not going to see that type of quarterly improvement consistently moving out there, but we are driving long term towards that 10% operating profit. And it syncs from the supply-chain efficiencies from our integration, it's continued own-brand penetration. Obviously, recovery in our higher-margin categories, improvement in sales to existing customers which are still down. And that's in our core categories. And then the growth initiatives especially the Jan/San, but also furniture, promotional products and tech and Copy & Print that are going to drive the top line to really generate the long-term margin growth that we've committed to out there. So I hope that helps.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, so for operating and selling or actually SG&A cost for the quarter, I mean, they grew at about 45% rate to sales growth. So it's a very good quarter for cost. And you talked about the lower marketing expenses. What kind of, I mean, can you speak to
componenttext: John, so for operating and selling or actually SG&A cost for the quarter, I mean, they grew at about 45% rate to sales growth. So it's a very good quarter for cost. And you talked about the lower marketing expenses. What kind of, I mean, can you speak to how we should think about that rate of SG&A growth going forward? I mean, are the lower marketing expenses sticky enough where we should see that level of SG&A growth relative to sales? Or would you expect that to creep up, say, for the rest of the year?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the key really is the investments we've made in our growth initiatives that I mentioned earlier. We try and make those investments at a pace that allows us to maintain reasonable improvement in operating margin, but at the same time drive sales grow
componenttext: Well, the key really is the investments we've made in our growth initiatives that I mentioned earlier. We try and make those investments at a pace that allows us to maintain reasonable improvement in operating margin, but at the same time drive sales growth in all of those categories. So it may not be linear, I guess, as we go through the year. But I mentioned marketing expense is all about measuring the productivity of the marketing tools we use. I expect to see improvement there. Our G&A expenses have been very tightly managed and I expect to see improvement there as well. So I think you can expect us to sustain operating margin improvement throughout the year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, May 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And John, did you say that for guidance, you're looking at a 37.5% tax rate in guidance? Did I hear that right?
componenttext: And John, did you say that for guidance, you're looking at a 37.5% tax rate in guidance? Did I hear that right?

componenttext: For the second quarter, yes. For the year as a whole, we're anticipating, assuming Congress passes this extension provision into law, then it will return to 3% to 4.5% for the year.
