componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Third Quarter 2010 Staples, Inc. Earnings Conference Call. My name is Anne, and I will be your coordinator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to Laurel Lefebvre, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please proceed.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thanks for joining us for the Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Announcement. During today's call, we'll discuss some non-GAAP metrics to provide investors with useful information about our financial performance. Please see the Financial Measu
componenttext:
Good morning, and thanks for joining us for the Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Announcement. During today's call, we'll discuss some non-GAAP metrics to provide investors with useful information about our financial performance. Please see the Financial Measures & Other Data section of the Investor Information portion of staples.com for an explanation and reconciliation of such measures and other calculations of financial measures that we use to analyze our business.
I'd also like to remind you that certain information discussed on this call constitute forward-looking statements for purposes of the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by such forward-looking statements as a result of various important factors, including those discussed or referenced under the heading, Risk Factors, and elsewhere in Staples' latest 10-Q filed today.
Here to discuss Staples' Q3 performance and business outlook are Ron Sargent, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Miles, President and Chief Operating Officer; and John Mahoney, Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer. Also with us are Demos Parneros, President of U.S. Stores; and Joe Doody, President of North American Delivery.
During today's Q&A session, to allow everyone to participate on the call, we ask that you please limit your question to one per caller. If there's time remaining before we end the call at 9, we'll take additional questions, of course. Thanks. Ron?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Laurel, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. This morning, I'm pleased to announce Staples' third quarter results, and I'll start with the headlines. Total company sales were $6.5 billion for the quarter, up slightly compare
componenttext:
Thanks, Laurel, and good morning, everybody. Thanks for joining us today. This morning, I'm pleased to announce Staples' third quarter results, and I'll start with the headlines. 
Total company sales were $6.5 billion for the quarter, up slightly compared to Q3 of last year. We achieved adjusted earnings per share of $0.41 at the high end of our guidance, and cash flows were very strong. 
Last month, at our investor conference, we outlined our strategies to drive growth in North America and also our plans to profitably grow our International business. And during the third quarter, we made good progress against those plans, gaining traction in our growth initiatives, growing core office supplies and significantly improving our international profitability.  In North American retail, we achieved strong comps in copy and print and double-digit growth in our EasyTech business. In North American Delivery, we continued to see momentum on the top line, with 3% growth. And in our International segment, we grew a solid profit growth, with operating margins up 150 basis points compared to last year's third quarter.
With all the work that we've done in 2009 and 2010, we're poised for better top line trends going forward. For 2011, we're planning for sales growth in the low to mid-single digits and strong double-digit earnings growth. And while we're not expecting a rapid improvement of the economic environment, we do assume a slow steady recovery throughout the year.
We'll hit our sales targets by focusing on the four parts of our profitable growth strategy that we discussed at our Investor Day. We'll continue to grow our share of core office supplies, including growth and Staples' brand products. We'll take a big step forward in categories beyond office supply like facilities and breakroom products. We'll increase our mix of services, like copy and print and EasyTech. And we'll continue to make progress toward our goal of 7.5% operating margin in International. Doing all this, we'll generate a lot of cash that we will use to invest in our business and return to shareholders through dividends and share buybacks.
Turning to our business units, and I'll start with the North American delivery. Sales for the third quarter were $2.5 billion, an increase of 3% in U.S. dollars or 2% in local currency compared to Q3 of 2009. We grew the top line in the low-single digits in both contracts in Staples Business Delivery, and the gross top line trend continued to improve as we got back to flat sales after nine quarters of declines. 
Core office supplies and computers and accessories were strong during the third quarter. Office paper grew faster than the house, while ink was about flat for the quarter. Our Facilities and Breakroom initiative gained traction as we won several new multimillion dollar contracts during the third quarter. This year, we put a lot of effort into building a foundation to accelerate growth in facilities supplies. We've expanded our assortment, offering sharper prices and improved our systems to handle the unique requirements of this business. We have high expectations for growth in this category going forward.
NAD operating margin was flat compared to Q3 of 2009 at 8.9%, with nice leverage in contract. Our Contract business continues to benefit from Corporate Express synergies, will also investing in our growth initiatives. Strong margins in contract were offset by lower margins in Staples Business Delivery and Quill, as we invested in marketing and pricing to drive traffic in key categories like paper and facility supplies. 
During the third quarter, we also made strong progress with the physical integration of our supply chain. We upgraded 12 warehouses with the capability to serve both Staples and legacy Corporate Express customers, and service levels at these facilities are at all-time highs. The scope of our integration also includes our last mile delivery hubs. And so far this year, we've integrated over 45 locations, with about 15 more in process. And while we still have a lot of work to do in terms of integrating the supply chain network, launching a common front end and moving all our customers to the new system, we expect to get significant savings from this consolidation over the next several years. 
Moving on to North American Retail, sales for the third quarter were $2.6 billion, an increase of 1% in U.S. dollars compared to Q3 of 2009. Third quarter same-store sales declined 1%, with the strength in core office supplies, EasyTech and copy and print, offset by softness in business machines and computers. Computers were slightly negative, as we cycled last year's launch of Windows 7 late in the quarter. This added about a point to our Q3 comp last year. Consumables like ink and paper were in line with the house.
We are pleased with our back-to-school season, which was highlighted by strong customer demand for core supplies. This year, customers were required to hit a $5 minimum purchase threshold to be able to take advantage of our best offers, which drove up average order size and improved our margins.  North American Retail operating margin increased 47 basis points to 10.6% for the third quarter, as we improved product margins and recorded lower depreciation expense. We also saw strong growth in our high-margin services businesses like Copy and Print and EasyTech.
During the third quarter, Copy and Print achieved mid single-digit comps. We're seeing a great response for mid-market customers who were serving at retail through our outside sales force. And we continue to invest in copies and our remodels, as well as marketing to drive awareness.  Our EasyTech business is also gaining momentum with strong double-digit growth during the third quarter. We remain on track to exceed $100 million in EasyTech sales for the year in North America. We've seen a great response to our traffic driving deals like our free PC tune-up and 50% off tech service offers. 
We've also seen good results from our remodeling activities. We've now remodeled more than 550 stores with new EasyTech counters, and we'll complete another 200 in Q4.
With Black Friday about a week away, we've got big plans to drive traffic this holiday season. For most of the year, we have a strong focus on the needs of our small-business customers. But during the holidays, we also work on driving consumer traffic. This year, we're offering the latest tech products like the Kindle, web printers and flip video cameras. 
During the third quarter, we opened 10 stores. We closed one store, ending Q3 with 1,897 stores in North America. We remain on track to open about 40 new stores in North America for the full year. And looking out to next year, we are planning to open about the same number of stores as this year. 
And with that, I'll turn it over to Mike Miles to talk about international.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Ron. Good morning, everybody.  Sales for the third quarter in International were $1.4 billion, a decrease of about 4% in U.S. dollars or a decrease of about 1% in local currency compared to the same period last year. We're seeing steady quar
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Ron. Good morning, everybody.  Sales for the third quarter in International were $1.4 billion, a decrease of about 4% in U.S. dollars or a decrease of about 1% in local currency compared to the same period last year. We're seeing steady quarter-by-quarter improvement in local currency sales trend with 300 basis points of sequential improvement on a two-year basis during Q3. Operating margin for the International business was 4.3%, an increase of 150 basis points from the same period in 2009, almost a 50% increase in profit dollars versus last year. This was driven by strong margin improvement in both our European delivery and Australian businesses, reduced losses in the Printing Systems division, as well as lower amortization. It was somewhat offset by deleverage of fixed expenses on lower sales in European retail. We had flat year-over-year sales performance in local currency in our European Delivery business, and the team did an outstanding job managing expenses, driving almost 200 basis points of operating margin improvement.
As we discussed on last quarter's call, we weren't satisfied with the minus nine comp and European retail during Q2. While we didn't quite get back to positive comps for Europe as a whole during the third quarter, the minus two comp was a nice sequential improvement on both a one-year and two-year basis. Improving trend at retail was led by Germany and Portugal, which both had positive comps during the third quarter. A highlight is our German Retail business. We've taken a much more disciplined approach to our marketing programs. We've pulled back on using low-margin tech to drive traffic and instead have focused on driving sales of core office supply. I feel confident that the German Retail business is on the right track. Were profitable in every single store in Germany, and are making plans to ramp up new store growth there in 2011.
During the third quarter, we completed our acquisition of the remaining shares of Corporate Express Australia. Despite a slight decline on the top line in local currency, operating income increased 90 basis points. A few weeks ago, we launched staples.com.au, serving small business customers in both New South Wales and the Australian Capital territory. The Staples name is new to the Australian market, and our global experience will help us deliver a differentiated offer to small businesses there. We're using the European web platform for Australia and for China as we leverage our global strength to give customers an easy e-commerce experience.
In the Printing Systems Division, we achieved top line growth and low single digits in local currency. Over the last two years, PSD has reduced its cost structure by 25%. It will breakeven during the second half of 2010, providing a nice upside as we lap the operating losses and restructuring charges of 2009.
At our investor conference in October, I walked you through our plans to improve international operating margins from 2.3% last year to 7.5% over the coming years. We have a big opportunity to get our cost structure more in line with our North American businesses and we put the right team in place to take us there. 
During the first three quarters of this year, we've taken a big step forward, with year-to-date operating margin up more than 120 basis points. I'm confident that we'll end 2010 with international operating margins above 3.5%.  And over the next few years, we expect to bridge the gap between where we stand at year end and our 7.5% goal by focusing on a few key areas. First, we plan to achieve about 150 basis points of improvement through G&A savings. Second, we will get 100 basis points from merchandising initiatives, like better buying and increased penetration of staples brand products. Finally, I expect about 50 basis points each from supply chain, turning around or exiting unprofitable business units and improving business mix like mid-market contract and retail services. Sales growth would provide additional leverage and accelerate our achievement, but the 7.5% margin target is based on the size of the business we have today. 
And I'd like to turn it over to John to review our financials.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. Good morning, everybody. For the third quarter, total company sales were up slightly versus last year at $6.5 billion. The foreign exchange impact from the stronger U.S. dollar had a modest negative impact on the top line, with sales grow
componenttext:
Thank you, Mike. Good morning, everybody. For the third quarter, total company sales were up slightly versus last year at $6.5 billion. The foreign exchange impact from the stronger U.S. dollar had a modest negative impact on the top line, with sales growth rounding up to 1% in local currency for the quarter. 
Our third quarter GAAP earnings per share on a fully diluted basis increased 8% to $0.40 versus the third quarter of 2009. During Q3, the company recorded pretax integration and restructuring expense of $9 million or $0.01 cent per diluted share. Excluding these costs as well as the $16 million of pretax integration restructuring expense that we incurred during the third quarter of 2009, adjusted diluted earnings per share increased 5% to $0.41 versus $0.39 during Q3 of last year.  Gross profit margin improved by 49 basis points to 27.6% during Q3. This reflects improved product margins, as well as increased supply chain efficiencies. 
SG&A deleveraged seven basis points versus last year's third quarter to 19.3% of sales. This was driven by lower depreciation expense and expense management, offset by our investments in training, labor and marketing to support the growth initiatives.  Adjusted operating margin, excluding integration and restructuring expense, increased 60 basis points during the third quarter to 8.0% compared to Q3 of 2009.  As we've discussed on previous calls, our effective tax rate this year is 37.5% compared to 34.5% last year. In the third quarter, this drove approximately $14 million of additional tax expense. We expect our tax rate to return to above 34.5% in 2011, assuming no other changes to the tax laws.
Year-to-date capital expenditures came in at $246 million compared to $191 million that we spent on capital during the same period last year. With year-to-date operating cash flow of more than $1 billion, we've generated $750 million in free cash flow. We expect our capital expenditures for the year to be closer to $400 million versus our previous guidance of $450 million. And we're on track to generate more than $1 billion of free cash flow for the full year. During the third quarter, we repurchased 8 million shares for $156 million. With a $1.4 billion of cash and cash equivalents on our balance sheet and available lines of credit of more than $1.2 billion, our balance sheet remains strong.
Turning to guidance for the fourth quarter, we expect total company sales to increase in the low single-digits versus 2009. We expect adjusted earnings per share to be in the range of $0.39 to $0.41 for the fourth quarter and $1.27 to $1.29 for the full year. This excludes integration and restructuring expense of approximately $8 million in the fourth quarter and about $60 million for the full year. 
Looking out to 2011, we expect top line growth in the low to mid-single digits as our growth initiatives continue to gain traction and earnings per share in the range of $1.50 to $1.60. And we expect to generate more than $1 billion in free cash next year after spending about $500 million in capital expenditures as we invest in supply chains, systems, new stores, as well as our growth initiatives.
Thanks for listening this morning, and now I'll turn the call back over to Anne to moderate the Q&A.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I've got one question and one follow-up. On the first one, if you could talk about your ability to generate operating leverage in retail, particularly as it relates to gross margin, given the mix shift towards technology. I understand that you cycled Wind
componenttext: I've got one question and one follow-up. On the first one, if you could talk about your ability to generate operating leverage in retail, particularly as it relates to gross margin, given the mix shift towards technology. I understand that you cycled Windows 7, so maybe the tech mix shift was mispronounced as it had been, but this is the biggest retail leverage that I think you've shown in something like four years. So, any insights there about drivers and sustainability would be great.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I'll start with just the continued focus on what goes along with tech, which is the services and really, our selling initiatives that we've put in place. We've worked hard to train associates throughout the entire country and it's really starting
componenttext: I guess I'll start with just the continued focus on what goes along with tech, which is the services and really, our selling initiatives that we've put in place. We've worked hard to train associates throughout the entire country and it's really starting to pay off. So that along with the remodel initiatives of over 700 stores remodeled by the end of the year, our EasyTech initiatives, and that's going to take hold. And then finally, the work that we've done with our Copy & Print business, both in-store, the remodels and the account reps out on the street are beginning to take hold as well. So I'd say that those are the big drivers.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess my follow-up relates on your investments, your new business investments in particular, can you help quantify perhaps the dollars that you're putting against these investments on the SG&A line and perhaps the revenue that they're driving at tod
componenttext: And I guess my follow-up relates on your investments, your new business investments in particular, can you help quantify perhaps the dollars that you're putting against these investments on the SG&A line and perhaps the revenue that they're driving at today, just to understand how material they are to the results here in the third quarter.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, of course, we arent going to disclose all the details of exactly how this business runs. There's a big combination of capitals, you've heard about the number of projects we've done in remodeling stores. And so you can imagine that we've got a sub
componenttext: Well, of course, we arent going to disclose all the details of exactly how this business runs. There's a big combination of capitals, you've heard about the number of projects we've done in remodeling stores. And so you can imagine that we've got a substantial investment in G&A, both in terms of the people managing those activities, as well as the people developing the marketing and training capabilities that we have. So it does have an effect. And as I think you've heard, all of the growth initiatives, particularly in the Retail business with the services have been growing substantially faster than the rest of the business. And so as Demos said, that helps gross margin, but it also helps cover the G&A that we're adding in order to support those initiatives. So as you expect, as we track these initiatives, we're try to balance maintaining good operating income margins and pushing the capabilities we need to be able to accelerate the growth in all of those. It's a delicate balance but obviously, in retail, in the quarter, the team did a great job.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Matt, just to kind of reinforce that, I think,  Demos and John talked to strategy, but the retail team in the U.S. and Canada did a terrific job, just kind of managing the business very carefully, kind of managing the mix of business. Back-to-school, I th
componenttext: Matt, just to kind of reinforce that, I think,  Demos and John talked to strategy, but the retail team in the U.S. and Canada did a terrific job, just kind of managing the business very carefully, kind of managing the mix of business. Back-to-school, I think, was a nice surprise for us this year in terms of how that rolled out. So I think you've got to give a lot of credit to Demos and Steve Matyas and their teams.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Brad Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Brad Thomas with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up on the margins in North American Delivery. This was, I believe, the lowest quarter of margin improvement for the year despite the best top line results that we've seen in the year. I was hoping you could just talk a little bit more a
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up on the margins in North American Delivery. This was, I believe, the lowest quarter of margin improvement for the year despite the best top line results that we've seen in the year. I was hoping you could just talk a little bit more about the impact of the marketing and pricing on margins and how we should think about margins in the category of next few quarters and where that leverage point is with some of the investments that you're making great.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brad, well, first, as we said, there was a nice leverage in contracts. But that was offset by deleverage in both Staples Business Delivery, as well as Quill. And we clearly made investments in both marketing and pricing, focused on customer acquisiti
componenttext: Yes, Brad, well, first, as we said, there was a nice leverage in contracts. But that was offset by deleverage in both Staples Business Delivery, as well as Quill. And we clearly made investments in both marketing and pricing, focused on customer acquisitions, a little bit on awareness campaign in Quill, as well as facilities in breakroom. So those are the years that we really focused on. We realized that in the short term, that most of these investments do not have a positive impact on margin, but they're really the right things for the long-term growth of the business. We did see some upside to our trend line on sales. We feel real good about our customer base and the development of the customer base with our customer acquisition activity. And we're committed to continuing to see, to meet our long-term margin goal, but in the short term, I wouldn't expect that our short-term trends for sales and margin growth will differ dramatically at least in Q4 from Q3.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Kate McShane with Citi Investment Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Kate McShane with Citi Investment Research.

componenttext: Not in dollars, but I can tell you that in terms of mix, it's about -- Demos was saying about 6% of our retail sales. So I can do the math, but that's rough and tough of what it is, and it's been growing nicely. I mean, a few years ago, it's 5%, now it's 6%.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010

componenttext: And then my other question is about the independent dealers. With some of these independent dealers winning some of the consortium contracts, I wondered if you could comment on any other changes you're seeing in the competitive environment as a result of these players getting more aggressive.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Joe and his team have been very successful in this arena, and let me ask Joe Doody to answer that one.
componenttext: Yes, Joe and his team have been very successful in this arena, and let me ask Joe Doody to answer that one.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think there's -- clearly, they're trying to be able to band together to get some of the bigger contracts, as you saw in the U.S. communities' example. But they have been a strong competitor and the strongest of the independents have survived, but w
componenttext: Yes, I think there's -- clearly, they're trying to be able to band together to get some of the bigger contracts, as you saw in the U.S. communities' example. But they have been a strong competitor and the strongest of the independents have survived, but we continue to gain share in that mid-market, which is primarily where they are strongest. And we continue to invest heavily in customer acquisition in that area, and continue to expect to gain further share in that market moving forward. So a strong competition continues, but we continue to gain share in that market.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010

componenttext: And next quarter, we'll be prepared to, I think, talk a little bit more specifically about how we're doing against the U.S. communities specifically because that seems to be heating up.

componenttext: Definitely heating up, and one where we're going after it aggressively as we do all new business opportunities, but one that's a little too early to report the specific success examples, those are beginning as we speak.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010

componenttext: And with the customer acquisition you highlighted in your comments, was that more of the middle market level, or was it across the board?

componenttext: It's really across the board. The investment we made in the customer acquisition is not just in the mid-market. But also as I stated, it's in the Staples Business Delivery as well as Quill, so it also is in our small business areas as well.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on a topic that was started at the Investor Day. As you think about the wireless business, and you're push into adjacent categories, do you think that at some point in 2011, kind of the Staples machine really gets behind the wireless
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on a topic that was started at the Investor Day. As you think about the wireless business, and you're push into adjacent categories, do you think that at some point in 2011, kind of the Staples machine really gets behind the wireless test? I know you have 100 stores right now and maybe roll a national multi-carrier model because if you want to be successful in tablets, don't you really have to have some leadership in the smartphone business?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you're right. I think it is a growing category, and it's one that we are and we'll be getting behind, but Demos can talk specifically about it.
componenttext: I think you're right. I think it is a growing category, and it's one that we are and we'll be getting behind, but Demos can talk specifically about it.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're right. We've actually been testing the multicarrier model, as well as our single carrier model. We do plan on doing more wireless in 2011.  And you can actually do a lot of the tablet with or without the lighting it up in the store. Obviously, we p
componenttext: You're right. We've actually been testing the multicarrier model, as well as our single carrier model. We do plan on doing more wireless in 2011.  And you can actually do a lot of the tablet with or without the lighting it up in the store. Obviously, we prefer to light them up and get the wireless contract as well. So it's based on our radar. We're working on it and its part of the overall tech initiative that we're pushing forward with.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then we'll give some color on the tablet plans.
componenttext: And then we'll give some color on the tablet plans.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, the tablet, it's a really exciting plan. We're going to see the first of the tablets get into our assortment. There'll be very little in Q4, but we'll have one nationally within a couple of weeks. We'll have also a few sets only in our wirele
componenttext: Yes, I mean, the tablet, it's a really exciting plan. We're going to see the first of the tablets get into our assortment. There'll be very little in Q4, but we'll have one nationally within a couple of weeks. We'll have also a few sets only in our wireless stores, which we're very excited about. But really, it gets much more fun in probably the first quarter. We expect anywhere between 5 and 10, all the major players really will have their offering, and we are geared up and ready to go. Our team is ready. We've been really preparing for it, and intend on being a pretty important player in tablets overall. So that should be a good opportunity for us, for majority of 2011.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're seeing the kind of a gradual narrowing in North American Retail of the comp between you and your leading competitors. So do you think you're maintaining overall share and actually growing? And do you think you're maintaining or growing share of the
componenttext: We're seeing the kind of a gradual narrowing in North American Retail of the comp between you and your leading competitors. So do you think you're maintaining overall share and actually growing? And do you think you're maintaining or growing share of the customers who are returning to the market now that the economy is getting better?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just briefly, I can answer that one. I mean, comps are based on how you did the year before. And when you look at kind of our comps versus last year versus our competitors comps versus last year and you look at the two-year trend, I think it's clear that
componenttext: Just briefly, I can answer that one. I mean, comps are based on how you did the year before. And when you look at kind of our comps versus last year versus our competitors comps versus last year and you look at the two-year trend, I think it's clear that we're continuing to gain share. Do I think we're continuing to gain share at all parts of the business, Retail, Delivery, International? I think all of our internal data would indicate that we are.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And do you expect that to continue to be the case as the recovery unfolds? And do you think it's going to be as cost efficient as it has been throughout the downturn?
componenttext: And do you expect that to continue to be the case as the recovery unfolds? And do you think it's going to be as cost efficient as it has been throughout the downturn?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't have a lot of experience with downturns because this was really only the second one we've had in the last 10 years. But if anything, we picked up a lot more share coming out of recovery last time, because we invested heavily in the business d
componenttext: Yes, I don't have a lot of experience with downturns because this was really only the second one we've had in the last 10 years. But if anything, we picked up a lot more share coming out of recovery last time, because we invested heavily in the business during the downturn. This recession, unfortunately, we've had more time to invest in the business during the downtime. But the recovery, I think, we have big expectations and many of the things that we announced on our investor conference a couple of weeks ago, that stuff we've been working on, testing on and even rolling out over the last couple of years. So we're feeling pretty good about kind of a recovering economy.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Mike Baker with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Mike Baker with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So really, I guess to follow up on that last point, your sales guidance next year, better than this year and I think you said getting better throughout the year. So I guess what kind of economic outlook is that predicated on? And if you're not expecting a
componenttext: So really, I guess to follow up on that last point, your sales guidance next year, better than this year and I think you said getting better throughout the year. So I guess what kind of economic outlook is that predicated on? And if you're not expecting an economic recovery, is it primarily based on the type of share gains that you just described?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's a little of both. I think it's safe to say that we are seeing a slow steady improvement in all areas of the business. And recently, I think jobs growth would indicate things are getting a little better for the national economy, I think
componenttext: Well, I think it's a little of both. I think it's safe to say that we are seeing a slow steady improvement in all areas of the business. And recently, I think jobs growth would indicate things are getting a little better for the national economy, I think as well as a lot of the other economic indicators. I think on top of that, we're seeing really good progress in the areas where we are placing a lot of attention, whether that's the Services business or the Facility Supplies or technology or even kind of the core office supplies. So I think it's a combination of investments we've made, continuing to execute against our competitors, so maybe there's some share gain there. And then third of all, kind of in the backdrop of an improving economy. I don't think we're expecting a robust recovery next year, but I think we are expecting a continued progress with the national economy.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if I could ask one follow-up, I just didn't want to ask about pricing in the Retail business, so it sounds like you got a little aggressive in price in the Delivery business and that helped your gap between your competitors widen this quarter, again,
componenttext: And if I could ask one follow-up, I just didn't want to ask about pricing in the Retail business, so it sounds like you got a little aggressive in price in the Delivery business and that helped your gap between your competitors widen this quarter, again, in retail, it did narrow. Now you did have tough comparisons, I bet that's fair. But I'm wondering if your competitors are more aggressive in pricing in the back-to-school period than you were, and just general comments on what you're seeing promotionally there.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say not at all. I think the back-to-school promotional climate was consistent. I would say it was pretty aggressive across, not only OSS but the mass and other channels as well. But as John mentioned before, we had good back-to-school season. We'v
componenttext: I would say not at all. I think the back-to-school promotional climate was consistent. I would say it was pretty aggressive across, not only OSS but the mass and other channels as well. But as John mentioned before, we had good back-to-school season. We've got particularly good strength in our store supplies, back-to-school businesses, the weakness is really a little bit in computers, as we mentioned. So we're happy with back-to-school. And as far as just overall pricing, I'm sure Black Friday's going to be the normal crazy pricing that we see every year. And we intend to have a good day. We've got a great offer for the day, but don't see really anything materially different.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Colin McGranahan with Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Colin McGranahan with Sanford Bernstein.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: First question for Mike, just on the pacing of G&A reductions, I guess, 150 basis points would equate to something like $75 million. How do you think that will be spread out over the course of 2011? And do you think it will extend beyond 2011?
componenttext: First question for Mike, just on the pacing of G&A reductions, I guess, 150 basis points would equate to something like $75 million. How do you think that will be spread out over the course of 2011? And do you think it will extend beyond 2011?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yet, it will extend beyond 2011, Colin. And recognize, as I'm sure you do, the implementation costs on G&A reductions, which are principally people, come with some expense as well.  So you'll probably see more of it in terms of actually hitting the P&L in
componenttext: Yet, it will extend beyond 2011, Colin. And recognize, as I'm sure you do, the implementation costs on G&A reductions, which are principally people, come with some expense as well.  So you'll probably see more of it in terms of actually hitting the P&L in 2012 because the gains we get in 2011 will be offset to a large extent by the costs to implement those G&A reductions.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Mike, just on Australia, watching staple.com, can you talk about the catalog circulation plans there and eventually trying to build a larger business maybe both on the Catalog side and the Retail side?
componenttext: And then Mike, just on Australia, watching staple.com, can you talk about the catalog circulation plans there and eventually trying to build a larger business maybe both on the Catalog side and the Retail side?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's interesting, Colin. This will be the first dot-com business that we've gotten into, where we really led with the dot-com as opposed to having a Catalog business where dot-com kind of follows in behind it. We're going to see how far we can push t
componenttext: Yes, it's interesting, Colin. This will be the first dot-com business that we've gotten into, where we really led with the dot-com as opposed to having a Catalog business where dot-com kind of follows in behind it. We're going to see how far we can push this by using e-commerce and e-marketing techniques largely, although there's certainly a direct mail plan that goes with it. It's probably not as catalog-intense as the SPD businesses here and certainly, not as catalog intense as our direct businesses is in Europe are. We're on a soft launch at the moment. We're going to go much heavier in the first quarter of 2011, and then through a combination of direct marketing that you described, and also expanding the geographic spread today. As I said, we're just in the Sydney and Canberra areas. We will expand across the country throughout 2012.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Stephen Chick with FBR.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Stephen Chick with FBR.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have two questions. I guess, first, I want to make sure I took this down right. In North American retail, did you say that paper and ink was in line with the house for the quarter?
componenttext: I have two questions. I guess, first, I want to make sure I took this down right. In North American retail, did you say that paper and ink was in line with the house for the quarter?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I takes those down, down 1%. Do you know kind of what the market did in that category at retail? And is that something that's kind of consistent with what you talked about at the Analyst Day, with some of those categories maybe declining or deceleratin
componenttext: So I takes those down, down 1%. Do you know kind of what the market did in that category at retail? And is that something that's kind of consistent with what you talked about at the Analyst Day, with some of those categories maybe declining or decelerating a little bit in, I don't want to say relevance, but the paperless kind of move or would you expect that to accelerate from where you are here?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. When we talk to the Analyst Day, we were talking about kind of macro over 10, 15 years. We weren't talking about quarter-to-quarter change in paper consumption. When you look at ink, I think that our trend in ink was reflective gaining share, because
componenttext: No. When we talk to the Analyst Day, we were talking about kind of macro over 10, 15 years. We weren't talking about quarter-to-quarter change in paper consumption. When you look at ink, I think that our trend in ink was reflective gaining share, because I think ink is down -- because of the economy, I think ink is down a little more than we delivered. So we're pretty pleased that we picked up some share in ink. Paper, my guess is we were kind of about average. I don't know that we gained share or lost share in paper for the quarter, but it's a little hard for us to kind of know what's going from a quarter-to-quarter basis on market share. I don't think this is part of the secular decline and going to the paperless office.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then second, if I could, I remember you talked about reinvesting to increase the awareness of Quill. In SBD, is that the investments that you've made there, is that something that's kind of reacting to something that you're seeing competitively? And t
componenttext: And then second, if I could, I remember you talked about reinvesting to increase the awareness of Quill. In SBD, is that the investments that you've made there, is that something that's kind of reacting to something that you're seeing competitively? And then second to that, if I took it down right, the low single digit growth rate in SBD, I think it was running mid-single digit growth rate before. Would you speak to that a little bit?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: SBD have a very slight weakening in growth, Q2 to Q3, maybe 100 basis points, so not significant. As far as the pricing in SBD, it was really around Facilities and Breakroom products to really get and be more of a destination category there than a conveni
componenttext: SBD have a very slight weakening in growth, Q2 to Q3, maybe 100 basis points, so not significant. As far as the pricing in SBD, it was really around Facilities and Breakroom products to really get and be more of a destination category there than a convenience category. So we have to get our pricing in line, and we've done that. As a result of that, we're seeing very good growth beginning in that category. And as far as the marketing investment in SBD, where as you said, Steven, it's awareness building for Quill, in the case of SBD, it's really a customer acquisition spend from a marketing standpoint that's driving that. They're not due to any competitive activities in the marketplace.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Oliver Wintermantel with ISI.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Oliver Wintermantel with ISI.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: From a geographical standpoint, has the variance between your best and your worst markets narrowed since last year? Or is there still a significant difference, and if you could comment on Retail and Delivery, please.
componenttext: From a geographical standpoint, has the variance between your best and your worst markets narrowed since last year? Or is there still a significant difference, and if you could comment on Retail and Delivery, please.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Demos, you want to talk about the retail markets?
componenttext: Demos, you want to talk about the retail markets?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, there was little gap in our case between best and worst, actually, it's pretty consistent across the board. So I would say there's no real significant difference across the U.S.
componenttext: Actually, there was little gap in our case between best and worst, actually, it's pretty consistent across the board. So I would say there's no real significant difference across the U.S.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Joe, on the Delivery side, any geographic...
componenttext: And Joe, on the Delivery side, any geographic...

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not really, Oliver, we have seen some improvement in states like Florida and California, which back a year or so ago, were being hit more but were rather more in line with the house today. The only time we see a state that might pop up a lot from an NAB s
componenttext: Not really, Oliver, we have seen some improvement in states like Florida and California, which back a year or so ago, were being hit more but were rather more in line with the house today. The only time we see a state that might pop up a lot from an NAB standpoint is as we talked about at the Investor Day some of our in-state business, we've had good success in a particular state by taking on a state contract. And that may pop the business in that particular state in the short term. But generally speaking, there's been no major movement there.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: To follow up here in ticket versus traffic, could you please breakdown ticket versus traffic for us?
componenttext: To follow up here in ticket versus traffic, could you please breakdown ticket versus traffic for us?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ticket and traffic were fairly close, I think all within zero to 1% to plus 1%, I believe.
componenttext: Ticket and traffic were fairly close, I think all within zero to 1% to plus 1%, I believe.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think that one of the challenges this quarter is because the change in the way we did our back-to-school marketing, we didn't have as many of the transactions that are very low, less than $1 transaction if you taken out the penny offers. So the da
componenttext: Well, I think that one of the challenges this quarter is because the change in the way we did our back-to-school marketing, we didn't have as many of the transactions that are very low, less than $1 transaction if you taken out the penny offers. So the data is a little bit muddier. But overall, as we tried to estimate the impact of that, we would have said that traffic was probably slightly better, near flat, and average ticket was down a little bit, driving the aggregate down $1.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a reflection of fewer computer sales than maybe we expected.
componenttext: It's a reflection of fewer computer sales than maybe we expected.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Joscelyn MacKay with MorningStar.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Joscelyn MacKay with MorningStar.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm just trying to get a little bit more color on your potential for the Beyond Office Products. I mean, I know in your Analyst Day, you talked quite a bit about the overall categories slowly declining. And I know we said that core office products is abou
componenttext: I'm just trying to get a little bit more color on your potential for the Beyond Office Products. I mean, I know in your Analyst Day, you talked quite a bit about the overall categories slowly declining. And I know we said that core office products is about half of contracts. And then I know Demos mentioned that Ink and Toner is about a quarter of retail sales. Just trying to get a little -- kind of marry those two numbers maybe for the overall company or maybe a little bit more specific to get an apples-to-apples.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that try to describe the size of the markets in certainly, in technology and Copy & Print, I think you're well aware of those. So as you start to think about the Beyond Office Supply categories like Facilities and the Print business, as well as Pr
componenttext: I think that try to describe the size of the markets in certainly, in technology and Copy & Print, I think you're well aware of those. So as you start to think about the Beyond Office Supply categories like Facilities and the Print business, as well as Promotional Products. Obviously, facilities is the biggest. It's a multibillion-dollar opportunity for us. And it can certainly make a dent in the total company's sales growth overall. And I think the others are -- many of them aren't quite as big and a little more volatile than Promotional Products. But in the aggregate, each of them represents an opportunity to take the good solid office supplies base, the relationship we have with those customers, and to build on that by penetrating the account and selling them more products and drive the overall productivity.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And to be clear, we expect to continue to grow our sales in office supplies, core office supplies, including things like ink and paper and basic supplies. I think once people go back to work, I mean, we're going to continue to sell them a lot of office su
componenttext: And to be clear, we expect to continue to grow our sales in office supplies, core office supplies, including things like ink and paper and basic supplies. I think once people go back to work, I mean, we're going to continue to sell them a lot of office supplies. So I think what we're trying to do is kind of explain why we think the push into services and technology and copy and print made sense for us, long term, but I wouldn't be expecting continued declines in office supplies because we expect to be growing core office supplies going forward in all categories of the business.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Mitch Kaiser with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Mitch Kaiser with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about the eReader and tablet category? I know that you're going to have a couple of offerings here, and it sounds a lot more in Q1, just in terms of thinking about comp and margin implications. And then on some of the eReader c
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about the eReader and tablet category? I know that you're going to have a couple of offerings here, and it sounds a lot more in Q1, just in terms of thinking about comp and margin implications. And then on some of the eReader categories, is there opportunity to recognize recurring revenue stream with content downloads?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Demos, you want to start with that one?
componenttext: Demos, you want to start with that one?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Talk a little bit about eReaders first. I'm really excited about our launch of Kindle, which is in all our stores, and it's been received very well. It had very good sales on Kindle. We probably don't participate in the download portion of that busi
componenttext: Sure. Talk a little bit about eReaders first. I'm really excited about our launch of Kindle, which is in all our stores, and it's been received very well. It had very good sales on Kindle. We probably don't participate in the download portion of that business. We're basically selling the product. And we try to have a very nice attach rate on some of the items that you'd sell with Kindle and cases and so forth. We have one or two other off-brand products on the floor but essentially, that's the go-to-market brand for us. We've chosen to stay away from the other brands out there that some of the bookshops have and others have. As far as the download portion for the future, the answer is don't know, nothing at the moment. And we expect to have a really good season. Obviously, December's going to be a big month for the eReader category. There's also some good innovation in the category. There's been several new products, bigger products in terms of size, different form factors, so we expect the relationship to continue and to continue to build that business. As you mentioned earlier with tablets, we're very excited about becoming an important player in the tablet business. We're ready in terms of floor space, the preparation for training of our associates. As soon as the product is available, we'll be ready to go. So I think at this point, it's just a matter of each of the major players who have announced their plans to come through with delivering the product and we'll get it in our stores and get behind it. So don't have an actual forecast yet because we haven't sold any, but we expect to get after it pretty aggressively.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our PC share is pretty low, so we're expecting in opening the tablet business to be additive to our current technology mix.
componenttext: And our PC share is pretty low, so we're expecting in opening the tablet business to be additive to our current technology mix.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So as you sign people up then on the tablets on a go-forward basis, is there opportunities to recognize bounty for lighting up the month that you have talked about?
componenttext: So as you sign people up then on the tablets on a go-forward basis, is there opportunities to recognize bounty for lighting up the month that you have talked about?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, in those cases, where there is a light-up situation, the answer is absolutely yes.
componenttext: Yes, in those cases, where there is a light-up situation, the answer is absolutely yes.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Joe Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Joe Feldman with Telsey Advisory Group.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could maybe talk about the small business customer a little bit and drill down into that. Is there anything you're seeing? I would like to ask you guys that suggesting increased confidence among those guys? I know that the trends are all
componenttext: I was hoping you could maybe talk about the small business customer a little bit and drill down into that. Is there anything you're seeing? I would like to ask you guys that suggesting increased confidence among those guys? I know that the trends are all gradually improving. I'm trying to determine how much is a real comeback, or is it just easy comparisons compared to the past couple of years? And is there more appetite for private label or branded, discretionary versus nondiscretionary?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, we read the same stuff you do. I guess my gut tells me that things are really getting better. I think they're getting better slowly. We've seen nice growth in Staples brand this year, but we're also seeing good growth in some of the more disc
componenttext: Yes, I mean, we read the same stuff you do. I guess my gut tells me that things are really getting better. I think they're getting better slowly. We've seen nice growth in Staples brand this year, but we're also seeing good growth in some of the more discretionary items. And I'm not sure in real-time whether that's because we're doing a better job or investing or putting emphasis behind certain categories or in fact, things are getting better. I mean, but maybe one indicator might be furniture. Our furniture business, after being near death for many years, is starting to kind of be alive, and I've even seen some positive signs in some of furniture numbers recently. So I think that's -- you're right. It is easy comparisons, but I think people wouldn't be doing some of those discretionary buying if they didn't feel a little bit better about the state of the economy.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually for Mike, you mentioned Germany and doing a little more expansion there. I was just wondering if you could talk about what exactly you're seeing, what gives you the confidence. Also are you learning things you can take to other countries, maybe a
componenttext: Actually for Mike, you mentioned Germany and doing a little more expansion there. I was just wondering if you could talk about what exactly you're seeing, what gives you the confidence. Also are you learning things you can take to other countries, maybe around Europe or the rest of the world that would help to drive the Retail business?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Joe. As we look at Germany, it's a pretty attractive market for us on a number of dimensions. The economy there is probably the strongest in Europe right now. We've done a fair amount of market research that suggests that customers who are awar
componenttext: Yes, sure, Joe. As we look at Germany, it's a pretty attractive market for us on a number of dimensions. The economy there is probably the strongest in Europe right now. We've done a fair amount of market research that suggests that customers who are aware of the Staples experience and particularly those who have been in our stores accept the concept and really like what we offer in Retail there. We've got 50-some stores there, all of which are profitable, which is a pretty good sign that our concept works. And there's not really a pure-play competitor in the market. So given that there are only 57 stores there and we've got 81 million people in Germany, you do that math versus any of our North American markets, and you can see that there's a lot of upside to add stores. So we're excited about the prospect, and are looking to start opening stores again there over the next couple of years. I'm sure as we do that, there will be some things that we can learn for the other European markets. But it is true that the European markets are pretty different one from the other. And the challenges that our business in the U.K. is facing, for instance, are quite different than what we see in Germany. But from a new store standpoint, if we can be successful in Germany anywhere near to the extent that we can, that could be several years worth of new store growth just in that market, without us even having to look to other countries in Europe.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd just add that not only are our stores profitable, but the operating margin rate there is sufficient to be able to earn a return on investing for the capital of new stores there.
componenttext: I'd just add that not only are our stores profitable, but the operating margin rate there is sufficient to be able to earn a return on investing for the capital of new stores there.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Brian Nagel with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Brian Nagel with Oppenheimer.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, and recognizing we had a very detailed update in your business in late October, and we do have a quite fluid environment here. Maybe some comments on sales as far as in the fourth quarter, particularly as we get close to the holiday and some of you
componenttext: First, and recognizing we had a very detailed update in your business in late October, and we do have a quite fluid environment here. Maybe some comments on sales as far as in the fourth quarter, particularly as we get close to the holiday and some of your more extensive offerings for the holiday season this year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't want to start give kind of guidance. I mean, we're basically 2.5 weeks into the quarter. So the quarter, we've got the holiday selling in December. We've got the big January push, with everybody getting back to business. And I just think its way
componenttext: We don't want to start give kind of guidance. I mean, we're basically 2.5 weeks into the quarter. So the quarter, we've got the holiday selling in December. We've got the big January push, with everybody getting back to business. And I just think its way premature to give you any kind of direction, other than the guidance we've already provided.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The second question, again, it was a simple a question, but just looking -- you did lift the low end of the guidance -- for the low end of the EPS guidance in the release today versus what you've given in late October. Is that just simply a reflection of
componenttext: The second question, again, it was a simple a question, but just looking -- you did lift the low end of the guidance -- for the low end of the EPS guidance in the release today versus what you've given in late October. Is that just simply a reflection of the results coming a little bit better than you had guided to for the third quarter?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, it's probably more to do with the way earnings per share is calculated. As you know, the earnings per share calculation is discrete for each quarter and then the annual calculation and the average of the quarter, so the rounding tends to get you
componenttext: Actually, it's probably more to do with the way earnings per share is calculated. As you know, the earnings per share calculation is discrete for each quarter and then the annual calculation and the average of the quarter, so the rounding tends to get you there. The intention is to maintain the guidance that we had. It isnt to really increase it.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Anthony Chukumba with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Anthony Chukumba with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just had quick question in terms of the new EasyTech, I guess, the stores of the new EasyTech counters. You mentioned you have 550 stores and you will roll them out to another 200 -- a remodel, another 200 stores by year end. So I think it's pretty safe t
componenttext: Just had quick question in terms of the new EasyTech, I guess, the stores of the new EasyTech counters. You mentioned you have 550 stores and you will roll them out to another 200 -- a remodel, another 200 stores by year end. So I think it's pretty safe to assume that you're pretty happy with the performance of those stores. I was just wondering if you can give us any color even just directionally, in terms of the sales lift that you're getting in those stores for either just the EasyTech business and/or total technology product sales in those stores?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think we're prepared to share kind of what the technology is. But I can tell you that we've been kind of growing the EasyTech business 50% or so quarter after quarter after quarter. And we've been doing that with the offering and with the promotio
componenttext: I don't think we're prepared to share kind of what the technology is. But I can tell you that we've been kind of growing the EasyTech business 50% or so quarter after quarter after quarter. And we've been doing that with the offering and with the promotions. But frankly, we haven't even been doing it very well from a facility standpoint. I mean, we've been trying to grow this business with a little counter that's like three or four feet wide. And when we do expand to a full-blown EasyTech in our stores, the lift is pretty significant. Demos, you want to provide some color or commentary there?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add is that we actually are in the EasyTech business in every single store in the U.S. and Canada. And on the remodeled stores, I guess, we do have a small workspace as Ron mentioned. These remodeled stores really provide us with th
componenttext: The only thing I would add is that we actually are in the EasyTech business in every single store in the U.S. and Canada. And on the remodeled stores, I guess, we do have a small workspace as Ron mentioned. These remodeled stores really provide us with the opportunity to do a much better job and handling the work and really just demonstrated to the customers what a big commitment we've made to the business. Just lastly, I would say that we've actually been working on the people side for the last two years or more, and really feel good about the level of certification and training capability that we've built. And as we imagine the physical buildout, which is the easier part, having the people part done and having our team having done a good job on this, it's going to pay off. And we see a nice lift, not only in the tech sales in the EasyTech sales growth or in our related hardware sales that go along with that.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: But just to clarify, you are seeing a lift when you put in the EasyTech, specific EasyTech counter as opposed to storing just the smaller desk?
componenttext: But just to clarify, you are seeing a lift when you put in the EasyTech, specific EasyTech counter as opposed to storing just the smaller desk?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think we'd be doing any if we weren't seeing a lift, so absolutely.
componenttext: I don't think we'd be doing any if we weren't seeing a lift, so absolutely.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our final question today comes from the line of Dan Binder with Jefferies.
componenttext: And our final question today comes from the line of Dan Binder with Jefferies.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One on distribution. You mentioned both at your meeting in October as well as earlier, about the substantial work still in front of you on integration. And I was just curious, as you look at your longer term profit margin targets, maybe you
componenttext: Two questions. One on distribution. You mentioned both at your meeting in October as well as earlier, about the substantial work still in front of you on integration. And I was just curious, as you look at your longer term profit margin targets, maybe you could talk to a little bit on what that represents as you march towards those higher levels. In other words, what are the savings and what does the margin improvement ultimately look like as you get that distribution work to the level you want it at. And maybe in that conversation, if you can talk a little bit about where the square footage is on the network today and where it's ultimately going?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I'm not sure we're going to be able to kind of -- we're going through our normal explaining process, and I'm not sure we want to share year by year what we think we're going to get out of distribution and delivery. But I think it's pretty clear to us
componenttext: Yes, I'm not sure we're going to be able to kind of -- we're going through our normal explaining process, and I'm not sure we want to share year by year what we think we're going to get out of distribution and delivery. But I think it's pretty clear to us, and we talked about this a few weeks ago, that we do expect NAD to get to that 12% operating profit in the next several years, and North American Retail, 10%.  International, we've talked about 7.5%. But I think there's plans and there's credibility behind each one of those of how we're going to get there. Distribution, specifically, Joe, you want to continue the rest of it?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's going to be a part of it, Dan, as you could well imagine, but it's not going to be the majority of it by any means. But it is going to be an important part of it. We are leveraging today in spite of the fact. Even in this last quarter, we leveraged i
componenttext: It's going to be a part of it, Dan, as you could well imagine, but it's not going to be the majority of it by any means. But it is going to be an important part of it. We are leveraging today in spite of the fact. Even in this last quarter, we leveraged in spite of the fact that we've got some short-term cost that we're incurring to undertake the most projects we've ever undertaken in our history at one time. And we're in the midst of those here in the third and the fourth quarter, trying to that many of them done before we get into peak which is the month of January, and then we'll still continue to finish up some of those throughout 2011, and have the vast majority of them done in 2011. So it'll be a contributing factor for sure in our march to 12%, but will not be the majority of the differential between where we are today and getting to that level.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a sense of what the capacity reduction will look like over that time when you march through in August?
componenttext: Can you give us a sense of what the capacity reduction will look like over that time when you march through in August?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's fair to say that we will go down in terms of number of buildings. But as far as overall capacity, we plan to grow into some of the excess that we have today. And some of the excess that we have, we will consolidate into other buildings.
componenttext: Yes, I think it's fair to say that we will go down in terms of number of buildings. But as far as overall capacity, we plan to grow into some of the excess that we have today. And some of the excess that we have, we will consolidate into other buildings. And it's a market-by-market analysis, Dan, because in some markets where we do have duplicate buildings today, neither of the two buildings that are there can handle the combined volume that we have in that market. So it's a step at a time. It's not going to happen over the next year or so, given they have lease obligations, et cetera. But it's a very measured plan based upon really the relative performance of the different options that we look at within that market.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then finally, any parts of your business where you're seeing or expect to see meaningful inflation, deflationary trends?
componenttext: Then finally, any parts of your business where you're seeing or expect to see meaningful inflation, deflationary trends?

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I can't think of a single one. I mean, to the extent with...
componenttext: I can't think of a single one. I mean, to the extent with...

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Argentina.
componenttext: Argentina.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: A little inflation in Argentina. But you think about our business over time, I mean, typically, you see deflation in paper-based products and resin-based products. And obviously, oil's a little more expensive. But over time, it tends to be balanced out by
componenttext: A little inflation in Argentina. But you think about our business over time, I mean, typically, you see deflation in paper-based products and resin-based products. And obviously, oil's a little more expensive. But over time, it tends to be balanced out by the fact that technology goes the other way. I mean, the $2,000 average ticket size for a computer of five, six years ago is now $600, something like that. So I think, in general, we're not planning on any kind of significant impact from inflation for next year.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes today's question-and-answer session. I would now like to turn the call back over to Mr. Ron Sargent for closing remarks.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes today's question-and-answer session. I would now like to turn the call back over to Mr. Ron Sargent for closing remarks.

headline: Staples, Inc., Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: My only closing remarks is thanks, everybody, for your time this morning and your continued interest in our company, and we look forward to speaking to you all again very soon.
componenttext: My only closing remarks is thanks, everybody, for your time this morning and your continued interest in our company, and we look forward to speaking to you all again very soon.

componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, we thank you for your participation in today's conference. This concludes the presentation, and you may now disconnect. Have a good day.
